3.4. Regularity

Recall that the Haar functions ψ1,…,ψnsubscript𝜓1…subscript𝜓𝑛\psi_{1},\ldots,\psi_{n} form an orthogonal basis of ℓ2​[n]superscriptℓ2delimited-[]𝑛\ell^{2}[n]. However, this basis is not orthonormal, as the norm of each function ψjsubscript𝜓𝑗\psi_{j} on level ℓℓ\ell satisfies ∥ψj∥22=2ℓ/nsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜓𝑗22superscript2ℓ𝑛\mathinner{\lVert\psi_{j}\rVert}_{2}^{2}=2^{\ell}/n. Thus, every function x∈ℓ2​[n]𝑥superscriptℓ2delimited-[]𝑛x\in\ell^{2}[n] admits the orthogonal decomposition

x=∑j=1nλ​(x)j​ψjwhere ​λ​(x)j=n2ℓ​⟨ψj,x⟩.formulae-sequence𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛𝜆subscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝜓𝑗where 𝜆subscript𝑥𝑗𝑛superscript2ℓsubscript𝜓𝑗𝑥x=\sum_{j=1}^{n}\lambda(x)_{j}\,\psi_{j}\quad\text{where }\lambda(x)_{j}=\frac{n}{2^{\ell}}\langle\psi_{j},x\rangle.

The key property of the coefficient vector λ​(x)𝜆𝑥\lambda(x) is its approximate sparsity, which we can express via the ℓ1superscriptℓ1\ell^{1} norm.

Lemma 3.2 (Sparsity).

For any function x∈ℓ2​[n]𝑥superscriptℓ2delimited-[]𝑛x\in\ell^{2}[n], the coefficient vector λ​(x)𝜆𝑥\lambda(x) satisfies

∥λ​(x)∥1≤(L+2)​∥x∥1.subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜆𝑥1𝐿2subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑥1\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\lambda(x)\right\rVert}_{1}\leq(L+2)\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x\right\rVert}_{1}.
Proof.

First, let us prove the lemma for the indicator of any single point k∈[n]𝑘delimited-[]𝑛k\in[n], i.e. for x=1{k}𝑥subscript1𝑘x={\textbf{1}}_{\{k\}}. Here we have

λ​(x)j=n2ℓ​ψj​(k).𝜆subscript𝑥𝑗𝑛superscript2ℓsubscript𝜓𝑗𝑘\lambda(x)_{j}=\frac{n}{2^{\ell}}\psi_{j}(k).

By construction, any function ψjsubscript𝜓𝑗\psi_{j} on level ℓℓ\ell takes on three values: 00 and ±2ℓ/nplus-or-minussuperscript2ℓ𝑛\pm 2^{\ell}/n. Moreover, on any given level ℓ≥1ℓ1\ell\geq 1, the functions ψjsubscript𝜓𝑗\psi_{j} have disjoint support, so there is a single well-defined j=j​(k,ℓ)𝑗𝑗𝑘ℓj=j(k,\ell) for which k∈supp⁡(ψj)𝑘suppsubscript𝜓𝑗k\in\operatorname{supp}(\psi_{j}). Therefore, among all functions ψjsubscript𝜓𝑗\psi_{j} on a given level ℓ≥1ℓ1\ell\geq 1, only one can make λ​(x)j𝜆subscript𝑥𝑗\lambda(x)_{j} nonzero, namely the one with j=j​(k,ℓ)𝑗𝑗𝑘ℓj=j(k,\ell), and such a nonzero value always equals (n/2ℓ)​(±2ℓ/n)=±1𝑛superscript2ℓplus-or-minussuperscript2ℓ𝑛plus-or-minus1(n/2^{\ell})(\pm 2^{\ell}/n)=\pm 1. Summarizing, the level ℓ=0ℓ0\ell=0 contributes two nonzero coefficients λ​(x)j𝜆subscript𝑥𝑗\lambda(x)_{j}, while each further level ℓ∈{1,…,L}ℓ1…𝐿\ell\in\{1,\ldots,L\} contributes only one. Hence λ​(x)𝜆𝑥\lambda(x) has L+2𝐿2L+2 nonzero coefficients λ​(x)j𝜆subscript𝑥𝑗\lambda(x)_{j}, each taking values ±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1. Therefore, ∥λ​(x)∥1≤L+2subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜆𝑥1𝐿2\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\lambda(x)\right\rVert}_{1}\leq L+2.

To extend this bound to a general function x∈ℓ2​[n]𝑥superscriptℓ2delimited-[]𝑛x\in\ell^{2}[n], decompose it as x=∑k=1nx​(k)​1{k}𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛𝑥𝑘subscript1𝑘x=\sum_{k=1}^{n}x(k){\textbf{1}}_{\{k\}}. Then, by linearity, λ​(x)=∑k=1nx​(k)​λ​(1{k})𝜆𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛𝑥𝑘𝜆subscript1𝑘\lambda(x)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}x(k)\lambda({\textbf{1}}_{\{k\}}), so

∥λ​(x)∥1≤∑k=1n|x​(k)|​∥λ​(1{k})∥1.subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜆𝑥1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛𝑥𝑘subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜆subscript1𝑘1\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\lambda(x)\right\rVert}_{1}\leq\sum_{k=1}^{n}\mathinner{\!\left\lvert x(k)\right\rvert}\,\mathinner{\!\bigl{\lVert}\lambda({\textbf{1}}_{\{k\}})\bigr{\rVert}}_{1}.

The bound ∥λ​(1{k})∥1≤L+2subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜆subscript1𝑘1𝐿2\mathinner{\!\bigl{\lVert}\lambda({\textbf{1}}_{\{k\}})\bigr{\rVert}}_{1}\leq L+2 from the first part of the argument completes the proof of the lemma. ∎

We are ready to prove regularity. Consider the random function Z=∑j=1nΛj​ψj𝑍superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛subscriptΛ𝑗subscript𝜓𝑗Z=\sum_{j=1}^{n}\Lambda_{j}\psi_{j} constructed in Subsection 3.2. In our new notation, the coefficient vector of Z𝑍Z is λ(Z)=(Λ1,…,Λn)=:Λ\lambda(Z)=(\Lambda_{1},\ldots,\Lambda_{n})=\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\Lambda. We have for any x,y∈ℓ2​[n]𝑥𝑦superscriptℓ2delimited-[]𝑛x,y\in\ell^{2}[n]:

r​(x,y)≔densX⁡(x)densX⁡(y)=densΛ⁡(λ​(x))densΛ⁡(λ​(y)).≔𝑟𝑥𝑦subscriptdens𝑋𝑥subscriptdens𝑋𝑦subscriptdensΛ𝜆𝑥subscriptdensΛ𝜆𝑦r(x,y)\coloneqq\frac{\operatorname{dens}_{X}(x)}{\operatorname{dens}_{X}(y)}=\frac{\operatorname{dens}_{\Lambda}(\lambda(x))}{\operatorname{dens}_{\Lambda}(\lambda(y))}. (3.8)

To see this, recall that the map x↦λ​(x)maps-to𝑥𝜆𝑥x\mapsto\lambda(x) is a linear bijection on ℓ2​[n]superscriptℓ2delimited-[]𝑛\ell^{2}[n]. Hence for any ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 and for the unit ball B𝐵B of ℓ2​[n]superscriptℓ2delimited-[]𝑛\ell^{2}[n], we have

ℙ​{X∈x+ε​B​}ℙ​{X∈y+ε​B​}=ℙ​{Λ∈λ​(x)+ε​λ​(B)​}ℙ​{Λ∈λ​(y)+ε​λ​(B)​}.ℙ𝑋𝑥𝜀𝐵ℙ𝑋𝑦𝜀𝐵ℙΛ𝜆𝑥𝜀𝜆𝐵ℙΛ𝜆𝑦𝜀𝜆𝐵\frac{\mathbb{P}\left\{X\in x+\varepsilon B\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}{\mathbb{P}\left\{X\in y+\varepsilon B\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}=\frac{\mathbb{P}\left\{\Lambda\in\lambda(x)+\varepsilon\lambda(B)\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}{\mathbb{P}\left\{\Lambda\in\lambda(y)+\varepsilon\lambda(B)\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}.

Taking the limit on both sides as ε→0+→𝜀subscript0\varepsilon\to 0_{+} and applying the Lebesgue differentiation theorem yield (3.8).

By construction, the coefficients ΛisubscriptΛ𝑖\Lambda_{i} of the random vector Λ∈ℝnΛsuperscriptℝ𝑛\Lambda\in\mathbb{R}^{n} are Lap⁡(L+2)Lap𝐿2\operatorname{Lap}(L+2) i.i.d. random variables. Hence

densΛ⁡(z)=12​(L+2)​exp⁡(−∥z∥1L+2),z∈ℝn.formulae-sequencesubscriptdensΛ𝑧12𝐿2subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑧1𝐿2𝑧superscriptℝ𝑛\operatorname{dens}_{\Lambda}(z)=\frac{1}{2(L+2)}\exp\Big{(}-\frac{\mathinner{\!\left\lVert z\right\rVert}_{1}}{L+2}\Big{)},\quad z\in\mathbb{R}^{n}.

Thus,

r​(x,y)=exp⁡(∥λ​(y)∥1−∥λ​(x)∥1L+2).𝑟𝑥𝑦subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜆𝑦1subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜆𝑥1𝐿2r(x,y)=\exp\Bigg{(}\frac{\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\lambda(y)\right\rVert}_{1}-\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\lambda(x)\right\rVert}_{1}}{L+2}\Bigg{)}.

By the triangle inequality and Lemma 3.2, we have

∥λ​(y)∥1−∥λ​(x)∥1≤∥λ​(x)−λ​(y)∥1≤(L+2)​∥x−y∥1.subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜆𝑦1subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜆𝑥1subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜆𝑥𝜆𝑦1𝐿2subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦1\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\lambda(y)\right\rVert}_{1}-\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\lambda(x)\right\rVert}_{1}\leq\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\lambda(x)-\lambda(y)\right\rVert}_{1}\leq(L+2)\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x-y\right\rVert}_{1}.

Thus

r​(x,y)≤exp⁡(∥x−y∥1).𝑟𝑥𝑦subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦1r(x,y)\leq\exp(\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x-y\right\rVert}_{1}).

If we express the density in the form densX⁡(x)=1β​e−Vsubscriptdens𝑋𝑥1𝛽superscript𝑒𝑉\operatorname{dens}_{X}(x)=\frac{1}{\beta}e^{-V}, the bound we proved can be written as

exp⁡(V​(y)−V​(x))≤exp⁡(∥x−y∥1),𝑉𝑦𝑉𝑥subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦1\exp\left(V(y)-V(x)\right)\leq\exp(\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x-y\right\rVert}_{1}),

or V​(y)−V​(x)≤∥x−y∥1𝑉𝑦𝑉𝑥subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦1V(y)-V(x)\leq\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x-y\right\rVert}_{1}. Swapping x𝑥x with y𝑦y yields |V​(x)−V​(y)|≤∥x−y∥1𝑉𝑥𝑉𝑦subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦1\mathinner{\!\left\lvert V(x)-V(y)\right\rvert}\leq\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x-y\right\rVert}_{1}. The proof of Theorem 3.1 is complete. ∎

3.5. Optimality

The reader might wonder if the logarithmic factors are necessary in Theorem 3.1. While we do not know if this is the case for the bound (3.3), the logarithmic factor can not be completely removed from the uniform bound (3.2):

Proposition 3.3 (Logarithm is needed in (3.2)).

Let n≥4𝑛4n\geq 4 be a natural number and consider a probability density of the form f​(z)=1β​e−V​(z)𝑓𝑧1𝛽superscript𝑒𝑉𝑧f(z)=\frac{1}{\beta}e^{-V(z)} on ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}. Assume that the potential V𝑉V is 111-Lipschitz in the ℓ1superscriptℓ1\ell^{1}-norm, i.e. (3.1) holds. Then a random vector Z=(Z1,…,Zn)𝑍subscript𝑍1…subscript𝑍𝑛Z=(Z_{1},\ldots,Z_{n}) distributed according to the density f𝑓f satisfies

𝔼⁡max1≤k≤n⁡|Z1+⋯+Zk|≥18​log⁡n.𝔼subscript1𝑘𝑛subscript𝑍1⋯subscript𝑍𝑘18𝑛\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\max_{1\leq k\leq n}\mathinner{\!\left\lvert Z_{1}+\cdots+Z_{k}\right\rvert}\geq\frac{1}{8}\log n.
Proof.

Since triangle inequality yields ∥Z∥∞=max1≤k≤n⁡|Zk|≤2​max1≤k≤n⁡|Z1+⋯+Zk|subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑍subscript1𝑘𝑛subscript𝑍𝑘2subscript1𝑘𝑛subscript𝑍1⋯subscript𝑍𝑘\mathinner{\!\left\lVert Z\right\rVert}_{\infty}=\max_{1\leq k\leq n}\mathinner{\!\left\lvert Z_{k}\right\rvert}\leq 2\max_{1\leq k\leq n}\mathinner{\!\left\lvert Z_{1}+\cdots+Z_{k}\right\rvert}, it suffices to check that

𝔼⁡∥Z∥∞≥14​log⁡n.𝔼subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑍14𝑛\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert Z\right\rVert}_{\infty}\geq\frac{1}{4}\log n.

Assume for contradiction that this bound fails. Then, considering the cube

Q={z∈ℝn:∥z∥∞<12​log⁡n},𝑄𝑧superscriptℝ𝑛:subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑧12𝑛Q=\left\{z\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\;\mathinner{\!\left\lVert z\right\rVert}_{\infty}<\frac{1}{2}\log n\right\},

we obtain by Markov’s inequality that ℙ​{Z∈Q​}>1/2ℙ𝑍𝑄12\mathbb{P}\left\{Z\in Q\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}>1/2.

Let e1,…,ensubscript𝑒1…subscript𝑒𝑛e_{1},\ldots,e_{n} denote the standard basis vectors in ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n} and consider the following translates of the cube Q𝑄Q:

Qi=Q+12​log⁡(n)​ei,i=1,…,n.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑄𝑖𝑄12𝑛subscript𝑒𝑖𝑖1…𝑛Q_{i}=Q+\frac{1}{2}\log(n)\,e_{i},\quad i=1,\ldots,n.

Note the following two properties. First, the cubes Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{i} are disjoint. Second, since V𝑉V is 111-Lipschitz in the ℓ1superscriptℓ1\ell^{1}-norm, for each i=1,…,n𝑖1…𝑛i=1,\ldots,n, the densities of the random vectors Z𝑍Z and Z−12​log⁡(n)​ei𝑍12𝑛subscript𝑒𝑖Z-\frac{1}{2}\log(n)\,e_{i} and (Z1,…,Zn)subscript𝑍1…subscript𝑍𝑛(Z_{1},\ldots,Z_{n}) differ by a multiplicative factor of at most exp⁡(12​log⁡n)=n12𝑛𝑛\exp(\frac{1}{2}\log n)=\sqrt{n} pointwise. Therefore,

ℙ​{Z∈Qi​}=ℙ​{Z−12​log⁡(n)​ei∈Q​}≥1n​ℙ​{Z∈Q​}>12​n,i=1,…,n.formulae-sequenceℙ𝑍subscript𝑄𝑖ℙ𝑍12𝑛subscript𝑒𝑖𝑄1𝑛ℙ𝑍𝑄12𝑛𝑖1…𝑛\mathbb{P}\left\{Z\in Q_{i}\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}=\mathbb{P}\left\{Z-\frac{1}{2}\log(n)\,e_{i}\in Q\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}\geq\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\mathbb{P}\left\{Z\in Q\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}>\frac{1}{2\sqrt{n}},\quad i=1,\ldots,n.

Hence, using these two properties we get

1≥∑i=1nℙ​{Z∈Qi​}>n2.1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛ℙ𝑍subscript𝑄𝑖𝑛21\geq\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{P}\left\{Z\in Q_{i}\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}>\frac{\sqrt{n}}{2}.

It follows that n<4𝑛4n<4, which contradicts the assumption of the lemma. The proof is complete. ∎

3.6. Beyond the ℓ1superscriptℓ1\ell^{1} norm?

One may wonder why specifically the ℓ1superscriptℓ1\ell^{1} norm appears in the regularity property of Theorem 3.1. As we will see shortly, the regularity with respect to the ℓ1superscriptℓ1\ell^{1} norm is exactly what is needed in our applications to privacy. However, it might be interesting to see if there are natural extensions of Theorem 3.1 for general ℓpsuperscriptℓ𝑝\ell^{p} norms. The lemma below rules out one such avenue, showing that if a potential V𝑉V is Lipschitz with respect to the ℓpsuperscriptℓ𝑝\ell^{p} norm for some p>1𝑝1p>1, the corresponding random walk deviates at least polynomially fast (as opposed to logarithmically fast).

Proposition 3.4 (No boundedness for ℓpsuperscriptℓ𝑝\ell^{p}-regular potentials).

Let n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in\mathbb{N} and consider a probability density of the form f​(z)=1β​e−V​(z)𝑓𝑧1𝛽superscript𝑒𝑉𝑧f(z)=\frac{1}{\beta}e^{-V(z)} on ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}. Assume that the potential V𝑉V is 111-Lipschitz in the ℓpsuperscriptℓ𝑝\ell^{p}-norm. Then a random vector Z=(Z1,…,Zn)𝑍subscript𝑍1…subscript𝑍𝑛Z=(Z_{1},\ldots,Z_{n}) distributed according to the density f𝑓f satisfies

𝔼⁡|Z1+⋯+Zn|≥14​n1−1p.𝔼subscript𝑍1⋯subscript𝑍𝑛14superscript𝑛11𝑝\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\mathinner{\!\left\lvert Z_{1}+\cdots+Z_{n}\right\rvert}\geq\frac{1}{4}n^{1-\frac{1}{p}}.
Proof.

We can write Z1+⋯+Zn=⟨Z,u⟩subscript𝑍1⋯subscript𝑍𝑛𝑍𝑢Z_{1}+\cdots+Z_{n}=\langle Z,u\rangle where u=(1,…,1)𝖳𝑢superscript1…1𝖳u=(1,\ldots,1)^{\mathsf{T}}. Since ∥n−1p​u∥p=1subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝑛1𝑝𝑢𝑝1\mathinner{\lVert n^{-\frac{1}{p}}u\rVert}_{p}=1 and V𝑉V is 1-Lipschitz in the ℓpsuperscriptℓ𝑝\ell^{p} norm, the densities of the random vectors Z+n−1p​u𝑍superscript𝑛1𝑝𝑢Z+n^{-\frac{1}{p}}u and Z𝑍Z differ by a multiplicative factor of at most e𝑒e pointwise. Therefore,

𝔼⁡|⟨Z,u⟩|𝔼𝑍𝑢\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\langle Z,u\rangle\right\rvert} ≥e−1​𝔼⁡|⟨Z+n−1p​u,u⟩|absentsuperscript𝑒1𝔼𝑍superscript𝑛1𝑝𝑢𝑢\displaystyle\geq e^{-1}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\mathinner{\!\bigl{\lvert}\langle Z+n^{-\frac{1}{p}}u,u\rangle\bigr{\rvert}}
≥e−1​(|⟨n−1p​u,u⟩|−𝔼⁡|⟨Z,u⟩|)(by triangle inequality)absentsuperscript𝑒1superscript𝑛1𝑝𝑢𝑢𝔼𝑍𝑢(by triangle inequality)\displaystyle\geq e^{-1}\Big{(}\mathinner{\!\bigl{\lvert}\langle n^{-\frac{1}{p}}u,u\rangle\bigr{\rvert}}-\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\langle Z,u\rangle\right\rvert}\Big{)}\quad\text{(by triangle inequality)}
=e−1​(n1−1p−𝔼⁡|⟨Z,u⟩|).absentsuperscript𝑒1superscript𝑛11𝑝𝔼𝑍𝑢\displaystyle=e^{-1}\Big{(}n^{1-\frac{1}{p}}-\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\langle Z,u\rangle\right\rvert}\Big{)}.

Rearranging the terms, we deduce that

𝔼⁡|⟨Z,u⟩|≥e−11+e−1​n1−1p≥14​n1−1p,𝔼𝑍𝑢superscript𝑒11superscript𝑒1superscript𝑛11𝑝14superscript𝑛11𝑝\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\langle Z,u\rangle\right\rvert}\geq\frac{e^{-1}}{1+e^{-1}}n^{1-\frac{1}{p}}\geq\frac{1}{4}n^{1-\frac{1}{p}},

which completes the proof. ∎

In light of Theorem 3.1 and Proposition 3.4 it might be interesting to see if an obstacle remains for the density f​(z)=1β​e−V​(z)p𝑓𝑧1𝛽superscript𝑒𝑉superscript𝑧𝑝f(z)=\frac{1}{\beta}e^{-V(z)^{p}} for p>1𝑝1p>1.

4. Metric privacy

4.1. Private measures

The superregular random walk we just constructed will become the main tool in solving the following private measure problem. We are looking for a private and accurate algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} that transforms a probability measure μ𝜇\mu on a metric space (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) into another finitely-supported probability measure 𝒜​(μ)𝒜𝜇\mathcal{A}(\mu) on (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho).

We need to specify what we mean by privacy and accuracy here. Metric privacy offers a natural framework for our problem. Namely, we consider Definition 2.2 for the space (ℳ​(T),TV)ℳ𝑇TV(\mathcal{M}(T),\mathrm{TV}) of all probability measures on T𝑇T equipped with the TV metric (recalled in Section 2.2.1). Thus, for any pair of input measures μ𝜇\mu and μ′superscript𝜇′\mu^{\prime} on T𝑇T that are close in the TV metric, we would like the distributions of the (random) output measures 𝒜​(μ)𝒜𝜇\mathcal{A}(\mu) and 𝒜​(μ′)𝒜superscript𝜇′\mathcal{A}(\mu^{\prime}) to be close:

ℙ​{𝒜​(μ)∈S​}ℙ​{𝒜​(μ′)∈S​}≤exp⁡(α​∥μ−μ′∥TV).ℙ𝒜𝜇𝑆ℙ𝒜superscript𝜇′𝑆𝛼subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜇superscript𝜇′TV\frac{\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{A}(\mu)\in S\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}{\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{A}(\mu^{\prime})\in S\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}\leq\exp\left(\alpha\mathinner{\lVert\mu-\mu^{\prime}\rVert}_{\mathrm{TV}}\right). (4.1)

The accuracy will be measured via the Wasserstein distance (recalled in Section 2.2.2). We hope to make W1​(𝒜​(μ),μ)subscript𝑊1𝒜𝜇𝜇W_{1}(\mathcal{A}(\mu),\mu) as small as possible. The reason for choosing W1subscript𝑊1W_{1} as distance is that it allows us to derive accuracy guarantees for general Lipschitz statistics, as outlined below.

4.2. Synthetic data

The private measure problem has an immediate application for differentially private synthetic data. Let (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) be a compact metric space. We hope to find an algorithm ℬℬ\mathcal{B} that transforms the true data X=(X1,…,Xn)∈Tn𝑋subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛superscript𝑇𝑛X=(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n})\in T^{n} into synthetic data Y=(Y1,…,Ym)∈Tm𝑌subscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑚superscript𝑇𝑚Y=(Y_{1},\ldots,Y_{m})\in T^{m} for some m𝑚m such that the empirical measures

μX=1n​∑i=1nδXiandμY=1m​∑i=1mδYiformulae-sequencesubscript𝜇𝑋1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝛿subscript𝑋𝑖andsubscript𝜇𝑌1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝛿subscript𝑌𝑖\mu_{X}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\delta_{X_{i}}\quad\text{and}\quad\mu_{Y}=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\delta_{Y_{i}}

are close in the Wasserstein distance, i.e. we hope to make W1​(μX,μY)subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝑋subscript𝜇𝑌W_{1}(\mu_{X},\mu_{Y}) small. This would imply that synthetic data accurately preserves all Lipschitz statistics, i.e.

1n​∑i=1nf​(Xi)≈1m​∑i=1mf​(Yi)1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝑓subscript𝑋𝑖1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚𝑓subscript𝑌𝑖\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f(X_{i})\approx\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}f(Y_{i})

for any Lipschitz function f:T→ℝ:𝑓𝑇→ℝf\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}T\to\mathbb{R}.

This goal can be immediately achieved if we solve a version of the private measure problem, described in Section 4.1, with the additional requirement that 𝒜​(μ)𝒜𝜇\mathcal{A}(\mu) be an empirical measure. Indeed, define the algorithm ℬℬ\mathcal{B} by feeding the empirical measure μXsubscript𝜇𝑋\mu_{X} into 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, i.e. set ℬ​(X)=𝒜​(μX)ℬ𝑋𝒜subscript𝜇𝑋\mathcal{B}(X)=\mathcal{A}(\mu_{X}). The accuracy follows, and the differential privacy of ℬℬ\mathcal{B} can be seen as follows.

For any pair X,X′𝑋superscript𝑋′X,X^{\prime} of input data that differ in a single element, the corresponding empirical measures differ by at most 1/n1𝑛1/n with respect to the TV distance, i.e.

∥μX−μX′∥TV≤1n.subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜇𝑋subscript𝜇superscript𝑋′TV1𝑛\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mu_{X}-\mu_{X^{\prime}}\right\rVert}_{\mathrm{TV}}\leq\frac{1}{n}.

Then, for any subset S𝑆S in the output space, we can use (4.1) to get

ℙ​{ℬ​(X)∈S​}ℙ​{ℬ​(X′)∈S​}=ℙ​{𝒜​(μX)∈S​}ℙ​{𝒜​(μX′)∈S​}≤exp⁡(α​∥μ−μ′∥TV)≤exp⁡(α/n).ℙℬ𝑋𝑆ℙℬsuperscript𝑋′𝑆ℙ𝒜subscript𝜇𝑋𝑆ℙ𝒜subscript𝜇superscript𝑋′𝑆𝛼subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜇superscript𝜇′TV𝛼𝑛\frac{\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{B}(X)\in S\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}{\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{B}(X^{\prime})\in S\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}=\frac{\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{A}(\mu_{X})\in S\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}{\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{A}(\mu_{X^{\prime}})\in S\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}\leq\exp\left(\alpha\,\mathinner{\lVert\mu-\mu^{\prime}\rVert}_{\mathrm{TV}}\right)\leq\exp(\alpha/n).

Thus, if α=ε​n𝛼𝜀𝑛\alpha=\varepsilon n, the algorithm ℬℬ\mathcal{B} is ε𝜀\varepsilon-differentially private. Let us record this observation formally.

Lemma 4.1 (Private measure yields private synthetic data).

Let (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) be a compact metric space. Let 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} be an algorithm that inputs a probability measure on T𝑇T, and outputs something. Define the algorithm ℬℬ\mathcal{B} that takes data X=(X1,…,Xn)∈Tn𝑋subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛superscript𝑇𝑛X=(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n})\in T^{n} as an input, creates the empirical measure μXsubscript𝜇𝑋\mu_{X} and feeds it into the algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, i.e. set ℬ​(X)=𝒜​(μX)ℬ𝑋𝒜subscript𝜇𝑋\mathcal{B}(X)=\mathcal{A}(\mu_{X}). If 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is α𝛼\alpha-metrically private in the TV metric and α=ε​n𝛼𝜀𝑛\alpha=\varepsilon n, then ℬℬ\mathcal{B} is ε𝜀\varepsilon-differentially private.

Thus, our main focus from now on will be on solving the private measure problem; private synthetic data will follows as a consequence.

5. A private measure on the line

In this section, we construct a private measure on the interval [0,1]01[0,1]. Later we will extend this construction to general metric spaces.

5.1. Discrete input space

Let us start with a somewhat restricted goal, and then work toward wider generality. In this subsection, we will (a) assume that the input measure μ𝜇\mu is always supported on some fixed finite subset

Ω={ω1,…,ωn}where ​0≤ω1≤⋯≤ωn≤1formulae-sequenceΩsubscript𝜔1…subscript𝜔𝑛where 0subscript𝜔1⋯subscript𝜔𝑛1\Omega=\{\omega_{1},\ldots,\omega_{n}\}\quad\text{where }0\leq\omega_{1}\leq\cdots\leq\omega_{n}\leq 1

and (b) allow the output 𝒜​(μ)𝒜𝜇\mathcal{A}(\mu) to be a signed measure. We will measure accuracy with the Wasserstein distance.

5.1.1. Perturbing a measure by a superregular random walk

Apply the Superregular Random Walk Theorem 3.1 and rescale the random variables Zisubscript𝑍𝑖Z_{i} by setting Ui=(2/α)​Zisubscript𝑈𝑖2𝛼subscript𝑍𝑖U_{i}=(2/\alpha)Z_{i}. The regularity property of the random vector U=(U1,…,Un)𝑈subscript𝑈1…subscript𝑈𝑛U=(U_{1},\ldots,U_{n}) takes the form

densY⁡(x)densY⁡(y)≤exp⁡(α2​∥x−y∥1)for all ​x,y∈ℝn,formulae-sequencesubscriptdens𝑌𝑥subscriptdens𝑌𝑦𝛼2subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦1for all 𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑛\frac{\operatorname{dens}_{Y}(x)}{\operatorname{dens}_{Y}(y)}\leq\exp\left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x-y\right\rVert}_{1}\right)\quad\text{for all }x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{n}, (5.1)

and the boundedness property takes the form

max1≤k≤n⁡𝔼⁡|U1+⋯+Uk|≤C​log32⁡nα.subscript1𝑘𝑛𝔼subscript𝑈1⋯subscript𝑈𝑘𝐶superscript32𝑛𝛼\max_{1\leq k\leq n}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\mathinner{\!\left\lvert U_{1}+\cdots+U_{k}\right\rvert}\leq\frac{C\log^{\frac{3}{2}}n}{\alpha}. (5.2)

Let us make the algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} perturb the measure μ𝜇\mu on ΩΩ\Omega by the weights Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}, i.e. we set

𝒜​(μ)​(ωi)=μ​({ωi})+Ui,i=1,…,n.formulae-sequence𝒜𝜇subscript𝜔𝑖𝜇subscript𝜔𝑖subscript𝑈𝑖𝑖1…𝑛\mathcal{A}(\mu)(\omega_{i})=\mu(\{\omega_{i}\})+U_{i},\quad i=1,\ldots,n. (5.3)

5.1.2. Privacy

Any measure ν𝜈\nu on ΩΩ\Omega can be identified with the vector ν¯∈ℝn¯𝜈superscriptℝ𝑛\bar{\nu}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} by setting ν¯i=ν​({ωi})subscript¯𝜈𝑖𝜈subscript𝜔𝑖\bar{\nu}_{i}=\nu(\{\omega_{i}\}). Then, for any measure η𝜂\eta on ΩΩ\Omega, we have

dens𝒜​(μ)⁡(η)=densμ¯+Y⁡(η¯)=densY⁡(η¯−μ¯).subscriptdens𝒜𝜇𝜂subscriptdens¯𝜇𝑌¯𝜂subscriptdens𝑌¯𝜂¯𝜇\operatorname{dens}_{\mathcal{A}(\mu)}(\eta)=\operatorname{dens}_{\bar{\mu}+Y}(\bar{\eta})=\operatorname{dens}_{Y}(\bar{\eta}-\bar{\mu}). (5.4)

Fix two measures μ𝜇\mu and μ′superscript𝜇′\mu^{\prime} on ΩΩ\Omega. By above, we have

dens𝒜​(μ)⁡(η)dens𝒜​(μ′)⁡(η)subscriptdens𝒜𝜇𝜂subscriptdens𝒜superscript𝜇′𝜂\displaystyle\frac{\operatorname{dens}_{\mathcal{A}(\mu)}(\eta)}{\operatorname{dens}_{\mathcal{A}(\mu^{\prime})}(\eta)} =densY⁡(η¯−μ¯)densY⁡(η¯−μ′¯)(by (5.4))absentsubscriptdens𝑌¯𝜂¯𝜇subscriptdens𝑌¯𝜂¯superscript𝜇′(by (5.4))\displaystyle=\frac{\operatorname{dens}_{Y}(\bar{\eta}-\bar{\mu})}{\operatorname{dens}_{Y}(\bar{\eta}-\bar{\mu^{\prime}})}\quad\text{(by \eqref{eq: measure to vector})}
≤exp⁡(α2​∥μ¯−μ′¯∥1)(by (5.1))absent𝛼2subscriptdelimited-∥∥¯𝜇¯superscript𝜇′1(by (5.1))\displaystyle\leq\exp\left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\bar{\mu}-\bar{\mu^{\prime}}\right\rVert}_{1}\right)\quad\text{(by \eqref{eq: Y regularity})}
=exp⁡(α​∥μ−μ′∥TV)(by (2.5)).absent𝛼subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜇superscript𝜇′TV(by (2.5))\displaystyle=\exp\left(\alpha\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mu-\mu^{\prime}\right\rVert}_{\mathrm{TV}}\right)\quad\text{(by \eqref{eq: TV as L1})}.

This shows that the algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is α𝛼\alpha-metrically private in the TV metric.

5.1.3. Accuracy

If ν𝜈\nu and μ𝜇\mu are signed measures on ΩΩ\Omega, then with the definition (2.7) of the Wasserstein metric for signed measures, we have

W1​(ν,μ)subscript𝑊1𝜈𝜇\displaystyle W_{1}(\nu,\mu) =∫01|ν​([0,x])−μ​([0,x])|​𝑑xabsentsuperscriptsubscript01𝜈0𝑥𝜇0𝑥differential-d𝑥\displaystyle=\int_{0}^{1}|\nu([0,x])-\mu([0,x])|\,dx
=∫01|∑i:ωi≤x(ν({ωi})−∑i:ωi≤xμ({ωi})|dx\displaystyle=\int_{0}^{1}\left|\sum_{i\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\;\omega_{i}\leq x}(\nu(\{\omega_{i}\})-\sum_{i\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\;\omega_{i}\leq x}\mu(\{\omega_{i}\})\right|\,dx
=∑k=1n(ωk+1−ωk)​|∑i=1kν​({ωi})−∑i=1kμ​({ωi})|,absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛subscript𝜔𝑘1subscript𝜔𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘𝜈subscript𝜔𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘𝜇subscript𝜔𝑖\displaystyle=\sum_{k=1}^{n}(\omega_{k+1}-\omega_{k})\left|\sum_{i=1}^{k}\nu(\{\omega_{i}\})-\sum_{i=1}^{k}\mu(\{\omega_{i}\})\right|,

where we set ωn+1=1subscript𝜔𝑛11\omega_{n+1}=1.

Applying this general observation for ν=𝒜​(μ)𝜈𝒜𝜇\nu=\mathcal{A}(\mu) and using (5.3), we obtain

W1​(𝒜​(μ),μ)=∑k=1n(ωk+1−ωk)​|U1+⋯+Uk|.subscript𝑊1𝒜𝜇𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛subscript𝜔𝑘1subscript𝜔𝑘subscript𝑈1⋯subscript𝑈𝑘W_{1}(\mathcal{A}(\mu),\mu)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}(\omega_{k+1}-\omega_{k})\mathinner{\!\left\lvert U_{1}+\cdots+U_{k}\right\rvert}.

Take expectation on both sides and use (5.2) to conclude that

𝔼⁡W1​(𝒜​(μ),μ)≤C​log32⁡nα.𝔼subscript𝑊1𝒜𝜇𝜇𝐶superscript32𝑛𝛼\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\mathcal{A}(\mu),\mu)\leq\frac{C\log^{\frac{3}{2}}n}{\alpha}.

The following result summarizes what we have proved.

Proposition 5.1 (Input in discrete space, output signed measure).

Let ΩΩ\Omega be finite subset of [0,1]01[0,1] and let n=|Ω|𝑛Ωn=\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\Omega\right\rvert}. Let α>0𝛼0\alpha>0. There exists a randomized algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} that takes a probability measure μ𝜇\mu on ΩΩ\Omega as an input and returns a signed measure ν𝜈\nu on ΩΩ\Omega as an output, and with the following two properties.

  1. (i)

    (Privacy): the algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is α𝛼\alpha-metrically private in the TV metric.

  2. (ii)

    (Accuracy): for any input measure μ𝜇\mu, the expected accuracy of the output signed measure ν𝜈\nu in the Wasserstein distance is

    𝔼⁡W1​(ν,μ)≤C​log32⁡nα.𝔼subscript𝑊1𝜈𝜇𝐶superscript32𝑛𝛼\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\nu,\mu)\leq\frac{C\log^{\frac{3}{2}}n}{\alpha}.

Let ν𝜈\nu be the signed measure obtained in Proposition 5.1. Let ν^^𝜈\widehat{\nu} be a probability measure on ΩΩ\Omega that minimizes W1​(ν^,ν)subscript𝑊1^𝜈𝜈W_{1}(\widehat{\nu},\nu). (The minimizer could be non-unique.) Note that this is a convex problem, since by (LABEL:wassersteinformula), this problem is equivalent to minimizing

∑k=1n(ωk+1−ωk)​|∑i=1kν^​({ωi})−∑i=1kν​({ωi})|,superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛subscript𝜔𝑘1subscript𝜔𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘^𝜈subscript𝜔𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘𝜈subscript𝜔𝑖\sum_{k=1}^{n}(\omega_{k+1}-\omega_{k})\left|\sum_{i=1}^{k}\widehat{\nu}(\{\omega_{i}\})-\sum_{i=1}^{k}\nu(\{\omega_{i}\})\right|,

under the constraints ν^​({ωi})≥0^𝜈subscript𝜔𝑖0\widehat{\nu}(\{\omega_{i}\})\geq 0 and ∑i=1kν^​({ωi})=1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘^𝜈subscript𝜔𝑖1\sum_{i=1}^{k}\widehat{\nu}(\{\omega_{i}\})=1.

By minimality, W1​(ν^,ν)≤W1​(μ,ν)subscript𝑊1^𝜈𝜈subscript𝑊1𝜇𝜈W_{1}(\widehat{\nu},\nu)\leq W_{1}(\mu,\nu). So W1​(ν^,μ)≤W1​(ν^,ν)+W1​(ν,μ)≤2​W1​(μ,ν)subscript𝑊1^𝜈𝜇subscript𝑊1^𝜈𝜈subscript𝑊1𝜈𝜇2subscript𝑊1𝜇𝜈W_{1}(\widehat{\nu},\mu)\leq W_{1}(\widehat{\nu},\nu)+W_{1}(\nu,\mu)\leq 2W_{1}(\mu,\nu).

Proposition 5.2 (Private measure on a finite subset of the interval).

Let ΩΩ\Omega be finite subset of [0,1]01[0,1] and let n=|Ω|𝑛Ωn=\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\Omega\right\rvert}. Let α>0𝛼0\alpha>0. There exists a randomized algorithm ℬℬ\mathcal{B} that takes a probability measure μ𝜇\mu on ΩΩ\Omega as an input and returns a probability measure ν𝜈\nu on ΩΩ\Omega as an output, and with the following two properties.

  1. (i)

    (Privacy): the algorithm ℬℬ\mathcal{B} is α𝛼\alpha-metrically private in the TV metric.

  2. (ii)

    (Accuracy): for any input measure μ𝜇\mu, the expected accuracy of the output measure ν𝜈\nu in the Wasserstein distance is

    𝔼⁡W1​(ν,μ)≤C​log32⁡nα.𝔼subscript𝑊1𝜈𝜇𝐶superscript32𝑛𝛼\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\nu,\mu)\leq\frac{C\log^{\frac{3}{2}}n}{\alpha}.

5.2. Extending the input space to the interval

Next, we would like to extend our framework to a continuous setting, and allow measures to be supported by the entire interval [0,1]01[0,1]. We can do this by quantization.

5.2.1. Quantization

Fix n∈𝒩𝑛𝒩n\in\mathcal{N} and let 𝒩={ω1,…,ωn}𝒩subscript𝜔1…subscript𝜔𝑛\mathcal{N}=\{\omega_{1},\ldots,\omega_{n}\} be a (1/n)1𝑛(1/n)-net of [0,1]01[0,1]. Consider the proximity partition

[0,1]=I1∪⋯∪In01subscript𝐼1⋯subscript𝐼𝑛[0,1]=I_{1}\cup\cdots\cup I_{n}

where we put a point x∈[0,1]𝑥01x\in[0,1] into Iisubscript𝐼𝑖I_{i} if x𝑥x is closer to ωisubscript𝜔𝑖\omega_{i} that to any other points in 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N}. (We break any ties arbitrarily.)

We can quantize any signed measure ν𝜈\nu on [0,1]01[0,1] by defining

ν𝒩​({ωi})=ν​(Ii),i=1,…,n.formulae-sequencesubscript𝜈𝒩subscript𝜔𝑖𝜈subscript𝐼𝑖𝑖1…𝑛\nu_{\mathcal{N}}\left(\{\omega_{i}\}\right)=\nu(I_{i}),\quad i=1,\ldots,n. (5.5)

Obviously, ν𝒩subscript𝜈𝒩\nu_{\mathcal{N}} is a signed measure on 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N}. Moreover, if ν𝜈\nu is a measure, then so is ν𝒩subscript𝜈𝒩\nu_{\mathcal{N}}. And if ν𝜈\nu is a probability measure, then so is ν𝒩subscript𝜈𝒩\nu_{\mathcal{N}}. In the latter case, it follows from the construction that

W1​(ν,ν𝒩)≤1/n.subscript𝑊1𝜈subscript𝜈𝒩1𝑛W_{1}(\nu,\nu_{\mathcal{N}})\leq 1/n. (5.6)

(By definition of the net, transporting any point x𝑥x to the closest point ωisubscript𝜔𝑖\omega_{i} covers distance at most 1/n1𝑛1/n.)

Lemma 5.3 (Quantization is a contraction in TV metric).

Any signed measure ν𝜈\nu on [0,1]01[0,1] satisfies

∥ν𝒩∥TV≤∥ν∥TV.subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜈𝒩TVsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜈TV\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nu_{\mathcal{N}}\right\rVert}_{\mathrm{TV}}\leq\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nu\right\rVert}_{\mathrm{TV}}.
Proof.

Using (2.5), (5.5), and (2.4), we obtain

∥ν𝒩∥TV=12​∑i=1n|ν𝒩​({ωi})|=12​∑i=1n|ν​(Ii)|≤∥ν∥TV.subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜈𝒩TV12superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝜈𝒩subscript𝜔𝑖12superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝜈subscript𝐼𝑖subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜈TV\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nu_{\mathcal{N}}\right\rVert}_{\mathrm{TV}}=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\nu_{\mathcal{N}}(\{\omega_{i}\})\right\rvert}=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\nu(I_{i})\right\rvert}\leq\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nu\right\rVert}_{\mathrm{TV}}.

The lemma is proved. ∎

5.2.2. A private measure on the interval

Theorem 5.4 (Private measure on the interval).

Let α≥2𝛼2\alpha\geq 2. There exists a randomized algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} that takes a probability measure μ𝜇\mu on [0,1]01[0,1] as an input and returns a finitely-supported probability measure ν𝜈\nu on [0,1]01[0,1] as an output, and with the following two properties.

  1. (i)

    (Privacy): the algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is α𝛼\alpha-metrically private in the TV metric.

  2. (ii)

    (Accuracy): for any input measure μ𝜇\mu, the expected accuracy of the output measure ν𝜈\nu in the Wasserstein distance is

    𝔼⁡W1​(ν,μ)≤C​log32⁡αα.𝔼subscript𝑊1𝜈𝜇𝐶superscript32𝛼𝛼\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}\left(\nu,\mu\right)\leq\frac{C\log^{\frac{3}{2}}\alpha}{\alpha}.
Proof.

Take a measure μ𝜇\mu on [0,1]01[0,1], preprocess it by quantizing as in the previous subsection, and feed the quantized measure μ𝒩subscript𝜇𝒩\mu_{\mathcal{N}} into the algorithm ℬℬ\mathcal{B} of Proposition 5.2 for Ω=𝒩Ω𝒩\Omega=\mathcal{N}.

The contraction property (Lemma 5.3) ensures that

∥μ𝒩−μ𝒩′∥TV≤∥μ−μ′∥TV.subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜇𝒩subscriptsuperscript𝜇′𝒩TVsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜇superscript𝜇′TV\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mu_{\mathcal{N}}-\mu^{\prime}_{\mathcal{N}}\right\rVert}_{\mathrm{TV}}\leq\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mu-\mu^{\prime}\right\rVert}_{\mathrm{TV}}.

This and the privacy property of Proposition 5.2 for measures on 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} guarantee that quantization does not destroy privacy, i.e. the algorithm μ↦ℬ​(μ𝒩)maps-to𝜇ℬsubscript𝜇𝒩\mu\mapsto\mathcal{B}(\mu_{\mathcal{N}}) is still α𝛼\alpha-metrically private as claimed.

As for the accuracy, Proposition 5.2 for the measure μ𝒩subscript𝜇𝒩\mu_{\mathcal{N}} gives

𝔼⁡W1​(ℬ​(μ𝒩),μ𝒩)≤C​log32⁡nα.𝔼subscript𝑊1ℬsubscript𝜇𝒩subscript𝜇𝒩𝐶superscript32𝑛𝛼\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}\left(\mathcal{B}(\mu_{\mathcal{N}}),\mu_{\mathcal{N}}\right)\leq\frac{C\log^{\frac{3}{2}}n}{\alpha}.

Moreover, the accuracy of quantization (5.6) states that W1​(μ,μ𝒩)≤1/nsubscript𝑊1𝜇subscript𝜇𝒩1𝑛W_{1}(\mu,\mu_{\mathcal{N}})\leq 1/n. By triangle inequality, we conclude that

𝔼⁡W1​(ℬ​(μ𝒩),μ)≤1n+C​log32⁡nα.𝔼subscript𝑊1ℬsubscript𝜇𝒩𝜇1𝑛𝐶superscript32𝑛𝛼\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}\left(\mathcal{B}(\mu_{\mathcal{N}}),\mu\right)\leq\frac{1}{n}+\frac{C\log^{\frac{3}{2}}n}{\alpha}.

Taking n𝑛n to be the largest integer less than or equal to α𝛼\alpha yields the conclusion of the theorem. ∎

6. The Traveling Salesman Problem

In order to extend the construction of the private measure on the interval [0,1]01[0,1] to a general metric space (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho), a natural approach would be to map the interval [0,1]01[0,1] onto some space-filling curve of T𝑇T. Since a space filling curves usually are infinitely long, we should do this on the discrete level, for some δ𝛿\delta-net of T𝑇T rather than T𝑇T itself. In this section, we will bound length of such discrete space-filling curve in terms of the metric geometry of T𝑇T. In the next section, we will see how this bound determines the accuracy of a private measure in T𝑇T.

A natural framework for this step is related to Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP), which is a central problem in optimization and computer science, and whose history goes back to at least 1832 [6].

Let G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E) be an undirected weighted connected graph. We occasionally refer to the weights of the edges as lengths. A tour of G𝐺G is a connected walk on the edges that visits every vertex at least once, and returns to the starting vertex. The TSP is the problem of finding a tour of G𝐺G with the shortest length. Let us denote this length by TSP⁡(G)TSP𝐺\operatorname{TSP}(G).

Although it is NP-hard to compute TSP(G), or even to approximate it within a factor of 123/122123122123/122 [30], an algorithm of Christofides and Serdyukov [16, 43] from 1976 gives a 3/2323/2-approximation for TSP, and it was shown recently that the factor 3/2323/2 can be further improved [29].

6.1. TSP in terms of the minimum spanning tree

Within a factor of 222, the traveling salesman problem is equivalent to another key problem, namely the problem of finding the minimum spanning tree (MST) of G𝐺G. A spanning tree of G𝐺G is a subgraph that is a tree and which includes all vertices of G𝐺G. It always exists and can be found in polynomial time [33, 39]. A spanning tree of G𝐺G with the smallest length is called the minimum spanning tree of G𝐺G; we denote its length by MST⁡(G)MST𝐺\operatorname{MST}(G). The following equivalence is a folklore.

Lemma 6.1.

Any undirected weighted connected graph G𝐺G satisfies

MST⁡(G)≤TSP⁡(G)≤2​MST⁡(G).MST𝐺TSP𝐺2MST𝐺\operatorname{MST}(G)\leq\operatorname{TSP}(G)\leq 2\operatorname{MST}(G).
Proof.

For the lower bound, it is enough to find a spanning tree of G𝐺G of length bounded by TSP⁡(G)TSP𝐺\operatorname{TSP}(G). Consider the minimal tour of G𝐺G of length TSP⁡(G)TSP𝐺\operatorname{TSP}(G) as a subgraph of G𝐺G. Let T𝑇T be a spanning tree of the tour. Since the tour contains all vertices of G𝐺G, so does T𝑇T, and thus T𝑇T is a spanning tree of G𝐺G. Since T𝑇T is obtained by removing some edges of the tour, the length of T𝑇T is bounded by of the tour, which is TSP⁡(G)TSP𝐺\operatorname{TSP}(G). The lower bound is proved.

For the upper bound, note that dropping any edges of G𝐺G can only increase the value of TSP. Thus TSP of G𝐺G is bounded by the TSP of its spanning tree T𝑇T. Moreover, TSP of any tree T𝑇T equals twice the sum of lengths of the edges of T𝑇T. This can be seen by considering the depth-first search tour of T𝑇T, which starts at the root and explores as deep as possible along each branch before backtracking, see Figure 3. ∎

6.2. Metric TSP

Let (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) be a finite metric space. We can consider T𝑇T as a complete weighted graph, whose weights of edges are defined as the distances between the points. The TSP for (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) is known as metric TSP.

Although a tour can visit the same vertex of T𝑇T multiple times, this can be prevented by skipping the vertices previously visited. The triangle inequality shows that skipping can only decrease the length of the tour. Therefore, the shortest tour in a complete graph is always a Hamiltonian cycle, a walk that visits all vertices of T𝑇T exactly once before returning to the starting vertex. Let us record this observation:

Lemma 6.2.

The TSP of a finite metric space (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) equals the smallest length of a Hamiltonian cycle of T𝑇T.

6.3. A geometric bound on TSP

We would like to compute TSP⁡(T)TSP𝑇\operatorname{TSP}(T) in terms of the geometry of the metric space (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho). Here we will prove an upper bound on TSP⁡(T)TSP𝑇\operatorname{TSP}(T) in terms of the covering numbers. Recall that the covering number N​(T,ρ,ε)𝑁𝑇𝜌𝜀N(T,\rho,\varepsilon) is defined as the smallest cardinality of an ε𝜀\varepsilon-net of T𝑇T, or equivalently the smallest number of closed balls with centers in T𝑇T and radii ε𝜀\varepsilon whose union covers T𝑇T, see [48, Section 4.2].

Theorem 6.3 (TSP via covering numbers).

For any finite metric space (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho), we have

TSP⁡(T)≤16​∫0∞(N​(T,ρ,x)−1)​𝑑x.TSP𝑇16superscriptsubscript0𝑁𝑇𝜌𝑥1differential-d𝑥\operatorname{TSP}(T)\leq 16\int_{0}^{\infty}\left(N(T,\rho,x)-1\right)\,dx.
Proof.

Step 1: constructing a spanning tree. Let us construct a small spanning tree T0subscript𝑇0T_{0} of T𝑇T and use Lemma 6.1. Let εj=2−jsubscript𝜀𝑗superscript2𝑗\varepsilon_{j}=2^{-j}, j∈ℤ𝑗ℤj\in\mathbb{Z}, and let 𝒩jsubscript𝒩𝑗\mathcal{N}_{j} be εjsubscript𝜀𝑗\varepsilon_{j}-nets of T𝑇T with cardinalities |𝒩j|=N​(T,ρ,εj)subscript𝒩𝑗𝑁𝑇𝜌subscript𝜀𝑗\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{N}_{j}\right\rvert}=N(T,\rho,\varepsilon_{j}). Since T𝑇T is finite, we must have |𝒩j|=1subscript𝒩𝑗1\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{N}_{j}\right\rvert}=1 for all sufficiently small j𝑗j. Let j0subscript𝑗0j_{0} be the largest integer for which |𝒩j0|=1subscript𝒩subscript𝑗01\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{N}_{j_{0}}\right\rvert}=1.

At the root of T0subscript𝑇0T_{0}, let us put a single point that forms the net 𝒩j0subscript𝒩subscript𝑗0\mathcal{N}_{j_{0}}. At the next level, put all the points of the net 𝒩j0+1subscript𝒩subscript𝑗01\mathcal{N}_{j_{0}+1}, and connect them to the root by edges. The weights of these edges, which are defined as the distances of the points to the root, are all bounded by εj0subscript𝜀subscript𝑗0\varepsilon_{j_{0}}. At the next level, put all points of the net 𝒩j0+2subscript𝒩subscript𝑗02\mathcal{N}_{j_{0}+2}, and connect each such point to the closest point in the previous level 𝒩j0+1subscript𝒩subscript𝑗01\mathcal{N}_{j_{0}+1}. (Break any ties arbitrarily.) Since the latter set is a εj0+1subscript𝜀subscript𝑗01\varepsilon_{j_{0}+1}-net, the weights of all these edges are bounded by εj0+1subscript𝜀subscript𝑗01\varepsilon_{j_{0}+1}. Repeat these steps until the levels do not grow anymore, i.e. until the level contains all the points in T𝑇T; see Figure 4 for illustration.

If all the nets 𝒩jsubscript𝒩𝑗\mathcal{N}_{j} that make up the levels of the tree T0subscript𝑇0T_{0} are disjoint, then T0subscript𝑇0T_{0} is a spanning tree of T𝑇T. Assume that this is the case for time being.

Step 2: bounding the length of the tree. For each of the levels j=j0+1,j0+2,…𝑗subscript𝑗01subscript𝑗02…j=j_{0}+1,j_{0}+2,\ldots, the tree T0subscript𝑇0T_{0} has |𝒩j|subscript𝒩𝑗\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{N}_{j}\right\rvert} edges connecting the points of level j𝑗j to the level j−1𝑗1j-1, and each such edge has length (weight) bounded by εj−1subscript𝜀𝑗1\varepsilon_{j-1}. So MST⁡(T)MST𝑇\operatorname{MST}(T) is bounded by the sum of the lengths of the edges of T0subscript𝑇0T_{0}, i.e.

MST⁡(T)≤∑j=j0+1∞εj−1​|𝒩j|.MST𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑗subscript𝑗01subscript𝜀𝑗1subscript𝒩𝑗\operatorname{MST}(T)\leq\sum_{j=j_{0}+1}^{\infty}\varepsilon_{j-1}\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{N}_{j}\right\rvert}.

Step 3: bounding the sum by the integral. Our choice εj=2−jsubscript𝜀𝑗superscript2𝑗\varepsilon_{j}=2^{-j} yields εj−1=4​(εj−εj+1)subscript𝜀𝑗14subscript𝜀𝑗subscript𝜀𝑗1\varepsilon_{j-1}=4(\varepsilon_{j}-\varepsilon_{j+1}). Moreover, our choice of j0subscript𝑗0j_{0} yields |𝒩j|≥2subscript𝒩𝑗2\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{N}_{j}\right\rvert}\geq 2 for all j≥j0+1𝑗subscript𝑗01j\geq j_{0}+1, which implies |𝒩j|≤2​(|𝒩j|−1)subscript𝒩𝑗2subscript𝒩𝑗1\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{N}_{j}\right\rvert}\leq 2\left(\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{N}_{j}\right\rvert}-1\right) for such j𝑗j. Therefore

MST⁡(T)MST𝑇\displaystyle\operatorname{MST}(T) ≤8​∑j=j0+1∞(εj−εj+1)​(|𝒩j|−1)absent8superscriptsubscript𝑗subscript𝑗01subscript𝜀𝑗subscript𝜀𝑗1subscript𝒩𝑗1\displaystyle\leq 8\sum_{j=j_{0}+1}^{\infty}\left(\varepsilon_{j}-\varepsilon_{j+1}\right)\left(\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{N}_{j}\right\rvert}-1\right) (6.1)
=8​∑j=j0+1∞∫εj+1εj(N​(T,ρ,εj)−1)​𝑑x(since |𝒩j|=N​(T,ρ,εj))absent8superscriptsubscript𝑗subscript𝑗01superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜀𝑗1subscript𝜀𝑗𝑁𝑇𝜌subscript𝜀𝑗1differential-d𝑥(since |𝒩j|=N(T,ρ,εj))\displaystyle=8\sum_{j=j_{0}+1}^{\infty}\int_{\varepsilon_{j+1}}^{\varepsilon_{j}}\left(N(T,\rho,\varepsilon_{j})-1\right)dx\quad\text{(since $\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{N}_{j}\right\rvert}=N(T,\rho,\varepsilon_{j})$)}
≤8​∫0∞(N​(T,ρ,x)−1)​𝑑x.absent8superscriptsubscript0𝑁𝑇𝜌𝑥1differential-d𝑥\displaystyle\leq 8\int_{0}^{\infty}\left(N(T,\rho,x)-1\right)\,dx.

An application of Lemma 6.1 completes the proof.

Step 4: splitting. The argument above assumes that all levels 𝒩jsubscript𝒩𝑗\mathcal{N}_{j} of the tree T0subscript𝑇0T_{0} are disjoint. This assumption can be enforced by splitting the points of T𝑇T. If, for example, a point ω∈𝒩j𝜔subscript𝒩𝑗\omega\in\mathcal{N}_{j} is also used in 𝒩ksubscript𝒩𝑘\mathcal{N}_{k} for some k<j𝑘𝑗k<j, add to T𝑇T another a replica of ω𝜔\omega – a point ω′superscript𝜔′\omega^{\prime} that has zero distance to ω𝜔\omega and the same distances to all other points as ω𝜔\omega. Use ω𝜔\omega in 𝒩jsubscript𝒩𝑗\mathcal{N}_{j} and ω′superscript𝜔′\omega^{\prime} in 𝒩ksubscript𝒩𝑘\mathcal{N}_{k}. Preprocessing the metric space (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) by such splitting yields a pseudometric space (T′,ρ)superscript𝑇′𝜌(T^{\prime},\rho) in which all levels 𝒩jsubscript𝒩𝑗\mathcal{N}_{j} are disjoint, and whose TSP is the same. ∎

Remark 6.4 (Integrating up to the diameter).

Note that N​(T,ρ,x)=1𝑁𝑇𝜌𝑥1N(T,\rho,x)=1 for any x>diam⁡(T)𝑥diam𝑇x>\operatorname{diam}(T), since any single point makes an x𝑥x-net of T𝑇T for such x𝑥x. Therefore, the integrand in Theorem 6.3 vanishes for such x𝑥x, and we have

TSP⁡(T)≤16​∫0diam⁡(T)N​(T,ρ,x)​𝑑x.TSP𝑇16superscriptsubscript0diam𝑇𝑁𝑇𝜌𝑥differential-d𝑥\operatorname{TSP}(T)\leq 16\int_{0}^{\operatorname{diam}(T)}N(T,\rho,x)\,dx. (6.2)

6.4. Folding

It is a simple observation that an interval of length TSP⁡(T)TSP𝑇\operatorname{TSP}(T) can be embedded, or “folded”, into T𝑇T:

Proposition 6.5 (Folding).

For any finite metric space (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) there exists a finite subset ΩΩ\Omega of the interval [0,TSP⁡(T)]0TSP𝑇[0,\operatorname{TSP}(T)] and a 111-Lipschitz bijection F:Ω→T:𝐹Ω→𝑇F\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\Omega\to T.

Heuristically, the map F𝐹F “folds” the interval [0,TSP⁡(T)]0TSP𝑇[0,\operatorname{TSP}(T)] into the shortest Hamiltonian path of the metric space T𝑇T, see Figure 5. We can think of this as a space-filling curve of T𝑇T.

Proof.

Let us exploit the heuristic idea of folding. Fix a Hamiltonian cycle in T𝑇T of length TSP⁡(T)TSP𝑇\operatorname{TSP}(T), whose existence is given by Lemma 6.2. Formally, this means that we can label the elements of the space as T={z1,…,zn}𝑇subscript𝑧1…subscript𝑧𝑛T=\{z_{1},\ldots,z_{n}\} in such a way that the lengths

δi=ρ​(zi+1,zi),i=1,…,n−1,formulae-sequencesubscript𝛿𝑖𝜌subscript𝑧𝑖1subscript𝑧𝑖𝑖1…𝑛1\delta_{i}=\rho\left(z_{i+1},z_{i}\right),\quad i=1,\ldots,n-1,

satisfy ∑i=1n−1δi≤TSP⁡(T)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛1subscript𝛿𝑖TSP𝑇\sum_{i=1}^{n-1}\delta_{i}\leq\operatorname{TSP}(T). Define Ω={x1,…,xn}Ωsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛\Omega=\{x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}\} by

x1=0;xk=∑i=1k−1δi,k=2,…,n.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑥10formulae-sequencesubscript𝑥𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘1subscript𝛿𝑖𝑘2…𝑛x_{1}=0;\quad x_{k}=\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}\delta_{i},\;k=2,\ldots,n.

Then all xk≤TSP⁡(T)subscript𝑥𝑘TSP𝑇x_{k}\leq\operatorname{TSP}(T), so Ω⊂[0,TSP⁡(T)]Ω0TSP𝑇\Omega\subset[0,\operatorname{TSP}(T)] as claimed.

Note that for every k=1,…,n−1𝑘1…𝑛1k=1,\ldots,n-1 we have

ρ​(zk+1,zk)=δk=xk+1−xk.𝜌subscript𝑧𝑘1subscript𝑧𝑘subscript𝛿𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘1subscript𝑥𝑘\rho\left(z_{k+1},z_{k}\right)=\delta_{k}=x_{k+1}-x_{k}.

Then, for any integers 1≤k≤k+j≤n1𝑘𝑘𝑗𝑛1\leq k\leq k+j\leq n, triangle inequality and telescoping give

ρ​(zk+j,zk)𝜌subscript𝑧𝑘𝑗subscript𝑧𝑘\displaystyle\rho\left(z_{k+j},z_{k}\right) ≤ρ​(zk+j,zk+j−1)+ρ​(zk+j−1,zk+j−2)+⋯+ρ​(zk+1,zk)absent𝜌subscript𝑧𝑘𝑗subscript𝑧𝑘𝑗1𝜌subscript𝑧𝑘𝑗1subscript𝑧𝑘𝑗2⋯𝜌subscript𝑧𝑘1subscript𝑧𝑘\displaystyle\leq\rho\left(z_{k+j},z_{k+j-1}\right)+\rho\left(z_{k+j-1},z_{k+j-2}\right)+\cdots+\rho\left(z_{k+1},z_{k}\right)
=(xk+j−xk+j−1)+(xk+j−1−xk+j−2)+⋯+(xk+1−xk)absentsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑗subscript𝑥𝑘𝑗1subscript𝑥𝑘𝑗1subscript𝑥𝑘𝑗2⋯subscript𝑥𝑘1subscript𝑥𝑘\displaystyle=\left(x_{k+j}-x_{k+j-1}\right)+\left(x_{k+j-1}-x_{k+j-2}\right)+\cdots+\left(x_{k+1}-x_{k}\right)
=xk+j−xk.absentsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑗subscript𝑥𝑘\displaystyle=x_{k+j}-x_{k}.

This shows that the folding map F:xk↦zk:𝐹subscript𝑥𝑘maps-tosubscript𝑧𝑘F\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}x_{k}\mapsto z_{k} is a bijection that satisfies

ρ​(F​(x),F​(y))≤|x−y|for all ​x,y∈Ω.formulae-sequence𝜌𝐹𝑥𝐹𝑦𝑥𝑦for all 𝑥𝑦Ω\rho\left(F(x),F(y)\right)\leq\mathinner{\!\left\lvert x-y\right\rvert}\quad\text{for all }x,y\in\Omega.

In other words, F𝐹F is 111-Lipschitz. The proof is complete. ∎

7. A private measure on a metric space

We are ready to construct a private measure on an arbitrary compact metric space (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho). We do this as follows: (a) discretize T𝑇T replacing it with a finite δ𝛿\delta-net; (b) fold an interval of length TSP⁡(T)TSP𝑇\operatorname{TSP}(T) onto T𝑇T using Proposition 6.5; and (c) using this folding, pushforward onto T𝑇T the private measure on the interval constructed in Section 5. The accuracy of the resulting private measure on T𝑇T is determined by the length of the interval TSP⁡(T)TSP𝑇\operatorname{TSP}(T), which in turn can be expressed using the covering numbers of T𝑇T (Theorem 6.3).

7.1. Finite metric spaces

Let us start by extending Proposition 5.2 from a finite subset on [0,1]01[0,1] to a finite subset of (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho).

Proposition 7.1 (Private measure on a finite metric space).

Let (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) be a finite metric space and let n=|T|𝑛𝑇n=\mathinner{\!\left\lvert T\right\rvert}. Let α>0𝛼0\alpha>0. There exists a randomized algorithm ℬℬ\mathcal{B} that takes a probability measure μ𝜇\mu on T𝑇T as an input and returns a probability measure ν𝜈\nu on T𝑇T as an output, and with the following two properties.

  1. (i)

    (Privacy): the algorithm ℬℬ\mathcal{B} is α𝛼\alpha-metrically private in the TV metric.

  2. (ii)

    (Accuracy): for any input measure μ𝜇\mu, the expected accuracy of the output measure ν𝜈\nu in the Wasserstein distance is

    𝔼⁡W1​(ν,μ)≤C​log32⁡nα​TSP⁡(T).𝔼subscript𝑊1𝜈𝜇𝐶superscript32𝑛𝛼TSP𝑇\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\nu,\mu)\leq\frac{C\log^{\frac{3}{2}}n}{\alpha}\,\operatorname{TSP}(T).
Proof.

Applying Folding Proposition 6.5, we obtain an n𝑛n-element subset Ω⊂[0,TSP⁡(T)]Ω0TSP𝑇\Omega\subset[0,\operatorname{TSP}(T)] and a 111-Lipschitz bijection F:Ω→T:𝐹Ω→𝑇F\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\Omega\to T. Applying Proposition 5.2 and rescaling by the factor TSP⁡(T)TSP𝑇\operatorname{TSP}(T), we obtain an α𝛼\alpha-metrically private algorithm ℬℬ\mathcal{B} that transforms a probability measure μ𝜇\mu on ΩΩ\Omega into a probability measure ν𝜈\nu on ΩΩ\Omega, and whose accuracy is

𝔼⁡W1​(ν,μ)≤C​log32⁡nα​TSP⁡(T).𝔼subscript𝑊1𝜈𝜇𝐶superscript32𝑛𝛼TSP𝑇\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\nu,\mu)\leq\frac{C\log^{\frac{3}{2}}n}{\alpha}\,\operatorname{TSP}(T). (7.1)

Define a new metric ρ¯¯𝜌\bar{\rho} on ΩΩ\Omega by ρ¯​(x,y)=ρ​(F​(x),F​(y))¯𝜌𝑥𝑦𝜌𝐹𝑥𝐹𝑦\bar{\rho}(x,y)=\rho\left(F(x),F(y)\right). Since F𝐹F is 111-Lipschitz, we have ρ¯​(x,y)≤|x−y|¯𝜌𝑥𝑦𝑥𝑦\bar{\rho}(x,y)\leq\mathinner{\!\left\lvert x-y\right\rvert}. Note that the Wasserstein distance can only become smaller if the underlying metric is replaced by a smaller metric. Therefore, the bound (7.1), which holds with respect to the usual metric |x−y|𝑥𝑦\mathinner{\!\left\lvert x-y\right\rvert} on ΩΩ\Omega, automatically holds with respect to the smaller metric ρ¯​(x,y)¯𝜌𝑥𝑦\bar{\rho}(x,y).

It remains to note that (Ω,ρ¯)Ω¯𝜌(\Omega,\bar{\rho}) is isometric to (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho). So the accuracy result (7.1), which as we saw holds in (Ω,ρ¯)Ω¯𝜌(\Omega,\bar{\rho}), automatically transfers to (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) (by considering the pushforward measure). ∎

7.2. General metric spaces

Quantization allows us to pass from discrete metric spaces to general spaces. A similar technique was used in Section 5.2 for the interval [0,1]01[0,1]. We will repeat it here for a general metric space.

7.2.1. Quantization

Fix δ>0𝛿0\delta>0 and let 𝒩={ω1,…,ωn}𝒩subscript𝜔1…subscript𝜔𝑛\mathcal{N}=\{\omega_{1},\ldots,\omega_{n}\} be a δ𝛿\delta-net of T𝑇T such that n=|𝒩|=N​(T,ρ,δ)𝑛𝒩𝑁𝑇𝜌𝛿n=\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{N}\right\rvert}=N(T,\rho,\delta). Consider the proximity partition

T=I1∪⋯∪In𝑇subscript𝐼1⋯subscript𝐼𝑛T=I_{1}\cup\cdots\cup I_{n}

where we put a point x∈T𝑥𝑇x\in T into Iisubscript𝐼𝑖I_{i} if x𝑥x is closer to ωisubscript𝜔𝑖\omega_{i} that to any other points in 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N}. (We break any ties arbitrarily.)

We can quantize any signed measure ν𝜈\nu on T𝑇T by defining

ν𝒩​({ωi})=ν​(Ii),i=1,…,n.formulae-sequencesubscript𝜈𝒩subscript𝜔𝑖𝜈subscript𝐼𝑖𝑖1…𝑛\nu_{\mathcal{N}}\left(\{\omega_{i}\}\right)=\nu(I_{i}),i=1,\ldots,n.

Obviously, ν𝒩subscript𝜈𝒩\nu_{\mathcal{N}} is a signed measure on 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N}. Moreover, if ν𝜈\nu is a measure, then so is ν𝒩subscript𝜈𝒩\nu_{\mathcal{N}}. And if ν𝜈\nu is a probability measure, then so is ν𝒩subscript𝜈𝒩\nu_{\mathcal{N}}. In the latter case, it follows from the construction that

W1​(ν,ν𝒩)≤δ.subscript𝑊1𝜈subscript𝜈𝒩𝛿W_{1}(\nu,\nu_{\mathcal{N}})\leq\delta. (7.2)

(By definition of the net, transporting any point x𝑥x to the closest point ωisubscript𝜔𝑖\omega_{i} covers distance at most δ𝛿\delta.) Furthermore, Lemma 5.3 easily generalizes and yields

∥ν𝒩∥TV≤∥ν∥TV.subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜈𝒩TVsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜈TV\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nu_{\mathcal{N}}\right\rVert}_{\mathrm{TV}}\leq\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nu\right\rVert}_{\mathrm{TV}}. (7.3)

Finally, let us bound the TSP of the net 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} using Theorem 6.3. We trivially have N​(𝒩,ρ,x)≤|𝒩|=N​(T,ρ,δ)𝑁𝒩𝜌𝑥𝒩𝑁𝑇𝜌𝛿N(\mathcal{N},\rho,x)\leq\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{N}\right\rvert}=N(T,\rho,\delta) for any x>0𝑥0x>0. Moreover, since 𝒩⊂T𝒩𝑇\mathcal{N}\subset T, we also have N​(𝒩,ρ,x)≤N​(T,ρ,x/2)𝑁𝒩𝜌𝑥𝑁𝑇𝜌𝑥2N(\mathcal{N},\rho,x)\leq N(T,\rho,x/2), see [48, Exercise 4.2.10]. Using the former bound for x<2​δ𝑥2𝛿x<2\delta and the latter bound for x≥2​δ𝑥2𝛿x\geq 2\delta and applying (6.2), we obtain

TSP⁡(𝒩)TSP𝒩\displaystyle\operatorname{TSP}(\mathcal{N}) ≲∫0diam⁡(𝒩)N​(𝒩,ρ,x)​𝑑xless-than-or-similar-toabsentsuperscriptsubscript0diam𝒩𝑁𝒩𝜌𝑥differential-d𝑥\displaystyle\lesssim\int_{0}^{\operatorname{diam}(\mathcal{N})}N(\mathcal{N},\rho,x)\,dx
≤2​δ​N​(T,ρ,δ)+∫2​δdiam⁡(T)N​(T,ρ,x/2)​𝑑xabsent2𝛿𝑁𝑇𝜌𝛿superscriptsubscript2𝛿diam𝑇𝑁𝑇𝜌𝑥2differential-d𝑥\displaystyle\leq 2\delta N(T,\rho,\delta)+\int_{2\delta}^{\operatorname{diam}(T)}N(T,\rho,x/2)\,dx
