7.2.2. A private measure on a general metric space

Theorem 7.2 (Private measure on a metric space).

Let (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) be a compact metric space. Let α,δ>0𝛼𝛿0\alpha,\delta>0. There exists a randomized algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} that takes a probability measure μ𝜇\mu on T𝑇T as an input and returns a finitely-supported probability measure ν𝜈\nu on T𝑇T as an output, and with the following two properties.

  1. (i)

    (Privacy): the algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is α𝛼\alpha-metrically private in the TV metric.

  2. (ii)

    (Accuracy): for any input measure μ𝜇\mu, the expected accuracy of the output measure ν𝜈\nu in the Wasserstein distance is

    𝔼⁡W1​(ν,μ)≤2​δ+Cα​log32⁡(N​(T,ρ,δ))​∫δdiam⁡(T)N​(T,ρ,x)​𝑑x.𝔼subscript𝑊1𝜈𝜇2𝛿𝐶𝛼superscript32𝑁𝑇𝜌𝛿superscriptsubscript𝛿diam𝑇𝑁𝑇𝜌𝑥differential-d𝑥\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\nu,\mu)\leq 2\delta+\frac{C}{\alpha}\log^{\frac{3}{2}}\left(N(T,\rho,\delta)\right)\int_{\delta}^{\operatorname{diam}(T)}N(T,\rho,x)\,dx.
Proof.

Preprocess the input measure μ𝜇\mu by quantizing as in the previous subsection, and feed the quantized measure μ𝒩subscript𝜇𝒩\mu_{\mathcal{N}} into the algorithm ℬℬ\mathcal{B} of Proposition 7.1 for the metric space (𝒩,ρ)𝒩𝜌(\mathcal{N},\rho).

The contraction property (7.3) ensures that

∥μ𝒩−μ𝒩′∥TV≤∥μ−μ′∥TVsubscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜇𝒩subscriptsuperscript𝜇′𝒩TVsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜇superscript𝜇′TV\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mu_{\mathcal{N}}-\mu^{\prime}_{\mathcal{N}}\right\rVert}_{\mathrm{TV}}\leq\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mu-\mu^{\prime}\right\rVert}_{\mathrm{TV}}

for any two input measures μ𝜇\mu and μ′superscript𝜇′\mu^{\prime}. This and the privacy property in Proposition 7.1 for measures on 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} guarantee that quantization does not destroy privacy, i.e. the algorithm 𝒜:μ↦ℬ​(μ𝒩):𝒜𝜇maps-toℬsubscript𝜇𝒩\mathcal{A}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\mu\mapsto\mathcal{B}(\mu_{\mathcal{N}}) is still α𝛼\alpha-metrically private as claimed.

Next, the accuracy property in Proposition 7.1 for the measure μ𝒩subscript𝜇𝒩\mu_{\mathcal{N}} on 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} gives

𝔼⁡W1​(ℬ​(μ𝒩),μ𝒩)≤Cα​log32⁡(N​(T,ρ,δ))​TSP⁡(𝒩).𝔼subscript𝑊1ℬsubscript𝜇𝒩subscript𝜇𝒩𝐶𝛼superscript32𝑁𝑇𝜌𝛿TSP𝒩\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}\left(\mathcal{B}(\mu_{\mathcal{N}}),\mu_{\mathcal{N}}\right)\leq\frac{C}{\alpha}\log^{\frac{3}{2}}(N(T,\rho,\delta))\,\operatorname{TSP}(\mathcal{N}).

Moreover, the accuracy of quantization (7.2) states that W1​(μ,μ𝒩)≤δsubscript𝑊1𝜇subscript𝜇𝒩𝛿W_{1}(\mu,\mu_{\mathcal{N}})\leq\delta. By triangle inequality, we conclude that

𝔼⁡W1​(ℬ​(μ𝒩),μ)≤δ+Cα​log32⁡(N​(T,ρ,δ))​TSP⁡(𝒩).𝔼subscript𝑊1ℬsubscript𝜇𝒩𝜇𝛿𝐶𝛼superscript32𝑁𝑇𝜌𝛿TSP𝒩\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}\left(\mathcal{B}(\mu_{\mathcal{N}}),\mu\right)\leq\delta+\frac{C}{\alpha}\log^{\frac{3}{2}}(N(T,\rho,\delta))\,\operatorname{TSP}(\mathcal{N}).

Thus, by (7.4),

𝔼⁡W1​(ℬ​(μ𝒩),μ)≤δ+Cα​log32⁡(N​(T,ρ,δ))​∫δ/2diam⁡(T)/2N​(T,ρ,x)​𝑑x.𝔼subscript𝑊1ℬsubscript𝜇𝒩𝜇𝛿𝐶𝛼superscript32𝑁𝑇𝜌𝛿superscriptsubscript𝛿2diam𝑇2𝑁𝑇𝜌𝑥differential-d𝑥\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}\left(\mathcal{B}(\mu_{\mathcal{N}}),\mu\right)\leq\delta+\frac{C}{\alpha}\log^{\frac{3}{2}}(N(T,\rho,\delta))\,\int_{\delta/2}^{\operatorname{diam}(T)/2}N(T,\rho,x)\,dx.

Since N​(T,ρ,2​δ)≤N​(T,ρ,δ)𝑁𝑇𝜌2𝛿𝑁𝑇𝜌𝛿N(T,\rho,2\delta)\leq N(T,\rho,\delta), replacing δ𝛿\delta by 2​δ2𝛿2\delta completes the proof of the theorem. ∎

7.3. Private synthetic data

The output of the algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} in Theorem 7.2 is a finitely-supported probability measure ν𝜈\nu on T𝑇T. Quantization allows to transform ν𝜈\nu into an empirical measure

μY=1m​∑i=1mδYisubscript𝜇𝑌1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝛿subscript𝑌𝑖\mu_{Y}=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\delta_{Y_{i}} (7.5)

where Y1,…,Ymsubscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑚Y_{1},\ldots,Y_{m} is some finite sequence of elements of T𝑇T, in which repetitions are allowed. In other words, we can make the output of our algorithm a synthetic data Y=(Y1,…,Ym)𝑌subscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑚Y=(Y_{1},\ldots,Y_{m}). Let us record this observation.

Corollary 7.3 (Outputting an empirical measure).

Let (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) be a compact metric space. Let α,δ>0𝛼𝛿0\alpha,\delta>0. There exists a randomized algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} that takes a probability measure μ𝜇\mu on T𝑇T as an input and returns Y=(Y1,…,Ym)∈Tm𝑌subscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑚superscript𝑇𝑚Y=(Y_{1},\ldots,Y_{m})\in T^{m} for some m𝑚m as an output, and with the following two properties.

  1. (i)

    (Privacy): the algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is α𝛼\alpha-metrically private in the TV metric.

  2. (ii)

    (Accuracy): for any input measure μ𝜇\mu, the expected accuracy of the empirical measure μYsubscript𝜇𝑌\mu_{Y} in the Wasserstein distance is

    𝔼⁡W1​(μY,μ)≤3​δ+Cα​log32⁡(N​(T,ρ,δ))​∫δdiam⁡(T)N​(T,ρ,x)​𝑑x.𝔼subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝑌𝜇3𝛿𝐶𝛼superscript32𝑁𝑇𝜌𝛿superscriptsubscript𝛿diam𝑇𝑁𝑇𝜌𝑥differential-d𝑥\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}\left(\mu_{Y},\mu\right)\leq 3\delta+\frac{C}{\alpha}\log^{\frac{3}{2}}\left(N(T,\rho,\delta)\right)\int_{\delta}^{\operatorname{diam}(T)}N(T,\rho,x)\,dx.
Proof.

Since the output probability measure ν𝜈\nu in Theorem 7.2 is finitely supported, it has the form

ν=∑i=1rwi​δYi𝜈superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑟subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝛿subscript𝑌𝑖\nu=\sum_{i=1}^{r}w_{i}\,\delta_{Y_{i}}

for some natural number r𝑟r, positive weights wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} and elements Ri∈Tsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑇R_{i}\in T.

Let us quantize the weights wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} by the uniform quantizer with step 1/m1𝑚1/m where m𝑚m is a large integer. Namely, set

q​(wi)≔⌊m​wi⌋m.≔𝑞subscript𝑤𝑖𝑚subscript𝑤𝑖𝑚q(w_{i})\coloneqq\frac{\lfloor m\,w_{i}\rfloor}{m}.

Obviously, the total quantization error satisfies

κ≔∑i=1r(wi−q​(wi))∈[0,r/m].≔𝜅superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑟subscript𝑤𝑖𝑞subscript𝑤𝑖0𝑟𝑚\kappa\coloneqq\sum_{i=1}^{r}\left(w_{i}-q(w_{i})\right)\in[0,r/m]. (7.6)

To make the quantized weights a probability measure, let us add the total quantization error to any given weight, say the first. Thus, define

w1′≔q​(w1)+κandwi′≔q​(wi),i=2,…,rformulae-sequence≔subscriptsuperscript𝑤′1𝑞subscript𝑤1𝜅andformulae-sequence≔subscriptsuperscript𝑤′𝑖𝑞subscript𝑤𝑖𝑖2…𝑟w^{\prime}_{1}\coloneqq q(w_{1})+\kappa\quad\text{and}\quad w^{\prime}_{i}\coloneqq q(w_{i}),\;i=2,\ldots,r

and set

ν′≔∑i=1rwi′​δYi.≔superscript𝜈′superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑟subscriptsuperscript𝑤′𝑖subscript𝛿subscript𝑌𝑖\nu^{\prime}\coloneqq\sum_{i=1}^{r}w^{\prime}_{i}\,\delta_{Y_{i}}.

Note the three key properties of ν′superscript𝜈′\nu^{\prime}. First, since the weights wi′subscriptsuperscript𝑤′𝑖w^{\prime}_{i} sum to one, ν′superscript𝜈′\nu^{\prime} is a probability measure. Second, since ν′superscript𝜈′\nu^{\prime} is obtained from ν𝜈\nu by transporting a total mass of κ𝜅\kappa across the metric space T𝑇T, we have

W1​(ν,ν′)≤κ⋅diam⁡(T)≤rm⋅diam⁡(T)≤δsubscript𝑊1𝜈superscript𝜈′⋅𝜅diam𝑇⋅𝑟𝑚diam𝑇𝛿W_{1}(\nu,\nu^{\prime})\leq\kappa\cdot\operatorname{diam}(T)\leq\frac{r}{m}\cdot\operatorname{diam}(T)\leq\delta

where the second inequality follows from (7.6) and the last one by choosing m𝑚m large enough. Third, all quantized weights q​(wi)𝑞subscript𝑤𝑖q(w_{i}) belong to 1m​ℤ1𝑚ℤ\frac{1}{m}\mathbb{Z} by definition. Thus, κ=1−∑i=1rq​(wi)𝜅1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑟𝑞subscript𝑤𝑖\kappa=1-\sum_{i=1}^{r}q(w_{i}) is also in 1m​ℤ1𝑚ℤ\frac{1}{m}\mathbb{Z}. Therefore, all weights wi′subscriptsuperscript𝑤′𝑖w^{\prime}_{i} are in 1m​ℤ1𝑚ℤ\frac{1}{m}\mathbb{Z}, too. Hence, wi′=mi/msubscriptsuperscript𝑤′𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖𝑚w^{\prime}_{i}=m_{i}/m for some nonnegative integers misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i}. In other words,

ν′=1m​∑i=1rmi​δYi.superscript𝜈′1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑟subscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝛿subscript𝑌𝑖\nu^{\prime}=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{r}m_{i}\,\delta_{Y_{i}}.

Since ν′superscript𝜈′\nu^{\prime} is a probability measure, we must have ∑i=1rmi=msuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑟subscript𝑚𝑖𝑚\sum_{i=1}^{r}m_{i}=m. Redefine the sequence Y1,…,Ymsubscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑚Y_{1},\ldots,Y_{m} by repeating each element Yisubscript𝑌𝑖Y_{i} of the sequence Y1,…,Yrsubscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑟Y_{1},\ldots,Y_{r} exactly misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i} times. Thus ν′=1m​∑i=1mδYisuperscript𝜈′1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝛿subscript𝑌𝑖\nu^{\prime}=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\delta_{Y_{i}}, as required. ∎

Corollary 7.3 allows us to transform any true data X=(X1,…,Xn)𝑋subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛X=(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n}) into a private synthetic data Y=(Y1,…,Ym)𝑌subscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑚Y=(Y_{1},\ldots,Y_{m}). To do this, feed the algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} with the empirical measure on the true data μX=1n​∑i=1nδXisubscript𝜇𝑋1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝛿subscript𝑋𝑖\mu_{X}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\delta_{X_{i}}. Recall from Lemma 4.1 that if the algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is α𝛼\alpha-metrically private for α=ε​n𝛼𝜀𝑛\alpha=\varepsilon n, then the algorithm X↦Y=𝒜​(μX)maps-to𝑋𝑌𝒜subscript𝜇𝑋X\mapsto Y=\mathcal{A}(\mu_{X}) yields ε𝜀\varepsilon-differential private synthetic data. Let us record this observation:

Corollary 7.4 (Differentially private synthetic data).

Let (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) be a compact metric space. Let ε,δ>0𝜀𝛿0\varepsilon,\delta>0. There exists a randomized algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} that takes true data X=(X1,…,Xn)∈Tn𝑋subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛superscript𝑇𝑛X=(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n})\in T^{n} as an input and returns synthetic data Y=(Y1,…,Ym)∈Tm𝑌subscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑚superscript𝑇𝑚Y=(Y_{1},\ldots,Y_{m})\in T^{m} for some m𝑚m as an output, and with the following two properties.

  1. (i)

    (Privacy): the algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is ε𝜀\varepsilon-differentially private.

  2. (ii)

    (Accuracy): for any true data X𝑋X, the expected accuracy of the synthetic data Y𝑌Y is

    𝔼⁡W1​(μY,μX)≤3​δ+Cε​n​log32⁡(N​(T,ρ,δ))​∫δdiam⁡(T)N​(T,ρ,x)​𝑑x,𝔼subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝑌subscript𝜇𝑋3𝛿𝐶𝜀𝑛superscript32𝑁𝑇𝜌𝛿superscriptsubscript𝛿diam𝑇𝑁𝑇𝜌𝑥differential-d𝑥\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}\left(\mu_{Y},\mu_{X}\right)\leq 3\delta+\frac{C}{\varepsilon n}\log^{\frac{3}{2}}\left(N(T,\rho,\delta)\right)\int_{\delta}^{\operatorname{diam}(T)}N(T,\rho,x)\,dx,

    where μXsubscript𝜇𝑋\mu_{X} and μYsubscript𝜇𝑌\mu_{Y} denote the corresponding empirical measures.

An interested reader may now skip to Section 9.1 where we illustrate Corollary 7.4 for a specific example of the metric space, namely the d𝑑d-dimensional cube T=[0,1]d𝑇superscript01𝑑T=[0,1]^{d}.

Remark 7.5 (A computationally effective algorithm).

We will present a detailed discussion of the algorithmic aspects of the proposed synthetic data generation method in a forthcoming paper. Here, we only mention that our algorithm works in polynomial time444under the stipulation that an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-net (of polynomial cardinality) can be constructed in polynomial time with respect to the cardinality of the dataset. To be more precise, assuming that the input measure μ𝜇\mu is given by an oracle for any set A𝐴A, the oracle gives us μ​(A)𝜇𝐴\mu(A) and we need a polynomial number of calls to such an oracle.

8. A lower bound

This section is devoted to impossibility results, which yield lower bounds on the accuracy of any private measure on a general metric space (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho). While there may be a gap between our upper and lower bounds for general metric spaces, we will see in Section 9 that this gap vanishes asymptotically for spaces of Minkowski dimension d𝑑d.

The proof of the lower bound uses the geometric method pioneered by Hardt and Talwar [25]. A lower bound is more convenient to express in terms of packing rather than covering numbers. Recall that the packing number Npack​(T,ρ,ε)subscript𝑁pack𝑇𝜌𝜀{N_{\textrm{pack}}}(T,\rho,\varepsilon) of a compact metric space (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) is defined as the largest cardinality of an ε𝜀\varepsilon-separated subset of T𝑇T. The covering and packing numbers are equivalent up to a factor of 222:

Npack​(T,ρ,2​ε)≤N​(T,ρ,ε)≤Npack​(T,ρ,ε),subscript𝑁pack𝑇𝜌2𝜀𝑁𝑇𝜌𝜀subscript𝑁pack𝑇𝜌𝜀{N_{\textrm{pack}}}(T,\rho,2\varepsilon)\leq N(T,\rho,\varepsilon)\leq{N_{\textrm{pack}}}(T,\rho,\varepsilon), (8.1)

see [48, Lemma 4.2.8]. Thus, in all results of this section, packing numbers can be replaced by covering numbers at the cost of changing absolute constants.

8.1. A master lower bound

We first prove a general result that establishes limitations of metric privacy. To understand this statement better, it may be helpful to assume that ℳ0=ℳ1subscriptℳ0subscriptℳ1\mathcal{M}_{0}=\mathcal{M}_{1} and ρ0=ρ1subscript𝜌0subscript𝜌1\rho_{0}=\rho_{1} in the first reading.

Proposition 8.1 (A master lower bound).

Let ℳ0⊂ℳ1subscriptℳ0subscriptℳ1\mathcal{M}_{0}\subset\mathcal{M}_{1} be two subsets, and let ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i} be a metric on ℳisubscriptℳ𝑖\mathcal{M}_{i}, i=0,1𝑖01i=0,1. Assume that for some t,α>0𝑡𝛼0t,\alpha>0 we have

diam⁡(ℳ0,ρ0)≤1andNpack​(ℳ0,ρ1,t)>2​eα.formulae-sequencediamsubscriptℳ0subscript𝜌01andsubscript𝑁packsubscriptℳ0subscript𝜌1𝑡2superscript𝑒𝛼\operatorname{diam}(\mathcal{M}_{0},\rho_{0})\leq 1\quad\text{and}\quad{N_{\textrm{pack}}}(\mathcal{M}_{0},\rho_{1},t)>2e^{\alpha}.

Then, for any randomized algorithm 𝒜:ℳ0→ℳ1:𝒜subscriptℳ0→subscriptℳ1\mathcal{A}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\mathcal{M}_{0}\to\mathcal{M}_{1} that is α𝛼\alpha-metrically private with respect to the metric ρ0subscript𝜌0\rho_{0}, there exists x∈ℳ0𝑥subscriptℳ0x\in\mathcal{M}_{0} such that

𝔼⁡ρ1​(𝒜​(x),x)>t/4.𝔼subscript𝜌1𝒜𝑥𝑥𝑡4\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\rho_{1}\left(\mathcal{A}(x),x\right)>t/4.
Proof.

For contradiction, assume that

𝔼⁡ρ1​(𝒜​(x),x)≤t/4,𝔼subscript𝜌1𝒜𝑥𝑥𝑡4\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\rho_{1}\left(\mathcal{A}(x),x\right)\leq t/4, (8.2)

for all x∈ℳ0𝑥subscriptℳ0x\in\mathcal{M}_{0}. Let 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} be a t𝑡t-separated subset of the metric space (ℳ0,ρ1)subscriptℳ0subscript𝜌1(\mathcal{M}_{0},\rho_{1}) with cardinality

|𝒩|>2​eα.𝒩2superscript𝑒𝛼\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{N}\right\rvert}>2e^{\alpha}. (8.3)

The separation condition implies that the balls B​(y,ρ1,t/2)𝐵𝑦subscript𝜌1𝑡2B(y,\rho_{1},t/2) centered at the points y∈𝒩𝑦𝒩y\in\mathcal{N} and with radii t/2𝑡2t/2 are all disjoint.

Fix any reference point y∈ℳ0𝑦subscriptℳ0y\in\mathcal{M}_{0}. The disjointness of the balls yields

∑x∈𝒩ℙ​{𝒜​(y)∈B​(x,ρ1,t/2)​}≤1.subscript𝑥𝒩ℙ𝒜𝑦𝐵𝑥subscript𝜌1𝑡21\sum_{x\in\mathcal{N}}\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{A}(y)\in B(x,\rho_{1},t/2)\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}\leq 1. (8.4)

On the other hand, by the definition of α𝛼\alpha-metric privacy, for each x∈𝒩𝑥𝒩x\in\mathcal{N} we have:

ℙ​{𝒜​(y)∈B​(x,ρ1,t/2)​}≥exp⁡[−α​ρ0​(x,y)]⋅ℙ​{𝒜​(x)∈B​(x,ρ1,t/2)​}.ℙ𝒜𝑦𝐵𝑥subscript𝜌1𝑡2⋅𝛼subscript𝜌0𝑥𝑦ℙ𝒜𝑥𝐵𝑥subscript𝜌1𝑡2\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{A}(y)\in B(x,\rho_{1},t/2)\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}\geq\exp\left[-\alpha\rho_{0}(x,y)\right]\cdot\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{A}(x)\in B(x,\rho_{1},t/2)\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}.

The diameter assumption yields ρ0​(x,y)≤1subscript𝜌0𝑥𝑦1\rho_{0}(x,y)\leq 1. Furthermore, using the assumption (8.2) and Markov’s inequality, we obtain

ℙ​{𝒜​(x)∈B​(x,ρ1,t/2)​}=ℙ​{ρ1​(𝒜​(x),x)≤t/2​}≥12.ℙ𝒜𝑥𝐵𝑥subscript𝜌1𝑡2ℙsubscript𝜌1𝒜𝑥𝑥𝑡212\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{A}(x)\in B(x,\rho_{1},t/2)\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}=\mathbb{P}\left\{\rho_{1}\left(\mathcal{A}(x),x\right)\leq t/2\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}\geq\frac{1}{2}.

Combining the two bounds gives

ℙ​{𝒜​(y)∈B​(x,ρ1,t/2)​}≥12​eα.ℙ𝒜𝑦𝐵𝑥subscript𝜌1𝑡212superscript𝑒𝛼\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{A}(y)\in B(x,\rho_{1},t/2)\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}\geq\frac{1}{2e^{\alpha}}.

Substitute this into (8.4) to get

∑x∈𝒩12​eα≤1.subscript𝑥𝒩12superscript𝑒𝛼1\sum_{x\in\mathcal{N}}\frac{1}{2e^{\alpha}}\leq 1.

In other words, we conclude that |𝒩|≤2​eα𝒩2superscript𝑒𝛼\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{N}\right\rvert}\leq 2e^{\alpha}, which contradicts (8.3). The proof is complete. ∎

8.2. Metric entropy of the space of probability measures

For a given compact metric space (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho), we denote by ℳ​(T)ℳ𝑇\mathcal{M}(T) the collection of all Borel probability measures on T𝑇T. We are going to apply Proposition 8.1 for ℳ0=ℳ1=ℳ​(T)subscriptℳ0subscriptℳ1ℳ𝑇\mathcal{M}_{0}=\mathcal{M}_{1}=\mathcal{M}(T), for ρ1=subscript𝜌1absent\rho_{1}= Wasserstein metric and ρ0=subscript𝜌0absent\rho_{0}= TV metric. That proposition requires a lower bound on the packing number Npack​(ℳ​(T),W1,t/3)subscript𝑁packℳ𝑇subscript𝑊1𝑡3{N_{\textrm{pack}}}\left(\mathcal{M}(T),W_{1},t/3\right). In the next lemma, we relate this packing number to that of (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho). Essentially, it says that if T𝑇T is large, then there are a lot of probability measures on T𝑇T.

Proposition 8.2 (Metric entropy of the space of probability measures).

For any compact metric space (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) and every t>0𝑡0t>0, we have

Npack​(ℳ​(T),W1,t/3)≥exp⁡(c​Npack​(T,ρ,t)),subscript𝑁packℳ𝑇subscript𝑊1𝑡3𝑐subscript𝑁pack𝑇𝜌𝑡{N_{\textrm{pack}}}\left(\mathcal{M}(T),W_{1},t/3\right)\geq\exp\left(c{N_{\textrm{pack}}}(T,\rho,t)\right),

where c>0𝑐0c>0 is a universal constant.

The proof will use the following lemma.

Lemma 8.3 (A lower bound on the Wasserstein distance).

Let (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) be a t𝑡t-separated555This means that the distance between any two distinct points in T𝑇T is larger than t𝑡t. compact metric space. Then, for any pair of probability measures μ,ν𝜇𝜈\mu,\nu on T𝑇T, we have

W1​(μ,ν)≥μ​(Bc)​twhereB=supp⁡(ν).formulae-sequencesubscript𝑊1𝜇𝜈𝜇superscript𝐵𝑐𝑡where𝐵supp𝜈W_{1}(\mu,\nu)\geq\mu(B^{c})\,t\quad\text{where}\quad B=\operatorname{supp}(\nu).
Proof.

Suppose that γ𝛾\gamma is a coupling of μ𝜇\mu and ν𝜈\nu. Since ν𝜈\nu is supported on B𝐵B, we have γ​(Bc×Bc)≤γ​(T×Bc)=ν​(Bc)=0𝛾superscript𝐵𝑐superscript𝐵𝑐𝛾𝑇superscript𝐵𝑐𝜈superscript𝐵𝑐0\gamma(B^{c}\times B^{c})\leq\gamma(T\times B^{c})=\nu(B^{c})=0, which means that γ​(Bc×Bc)=0𝛾superscript𝐵𝑐superscript𝐵𝑐0\gamma(B^{c}\times B^{c})=0. Therefore

γ​(Bc×B)=γ​(Bc×T)−γ​(Bc×Bc)=μ​(Bc).𝛾superscript𝐵𝑐𝐵𝛾superscript𝐵𝑐𝑇𝛾superscript𝐵𝑐superscript𝐵𝑐𝜇superscript𝐵𝑐\gamma(B^{c}\times B)=\gamma(B^{c}\times T)-\gamma(B^{c}\times B^{c})=\mu(B^{c}).

Since the sets Bcsuperscript𝐵𝑐B^{c} and B𝐵B are disjoint, the separation assumption implies that ρ​(x,y)>t𝜌𝑥𝑦𝑡\rho(x,y)>t for all pairs x∈Bc𝑥superscript𝐵𝑐x\in B^{c} and y∈B𝑦𝐵y\in B. Thus,

∫T×Tρ​(x,y)​𝑑γ​(x,y)≥∫Bc×Bρ​(x,y)​𝑑γ​(x,y)≥t​γ​(Bc×B)=t​μ​(Bc).subscript𝑇𝑇𝜌𝑥𝑦differential-d𝛾𝑥𝑦subscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑐𝐵𝜌𝑥𝑦differential-d𝛾𝑥𝑦𝑡𝛾superscript𝐵𝑐𝐵𝑡𝜇superscript𝐵𝑐\int_{T\times T}\rho(x,y)\;d\gamma(x,y)\geq\int_{B^{c}\times B}\rho(x,y)\;d\gamma(x,y)\geq t\gamma(B^{c}\times B)=t\mu(B^{c}).

Since this holds for all coupling γ𝛾\gamma of μ𝜇\mu and ν𝜈\nu, the result follows. ∎

Lemma 8.4 (Many different measures).

Let (𝒩,ρ)𝒩𝜌(\mathcal{N},\rho) be a t𝑡t-separated compact metric space, and assume that |𝒩|≥2​n𝒩2𝑛\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{N}\right\rvert}\geq 2n for some n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in\mathbb{N}. Then there exists a family of at least exp⁡(c​n)𝑐𝑛\exp(cn) empirical measures on n𝑛n points of T𝑇T that are pairwise t/3𝑡3t/3-separated in the Wasserstein distance, where c>0𝑐0c>0 is a universal constant.

Proof.

Let μ=n−1​∑i=1nδXi𝜇superscript𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝛿subscript𝑋𝑖\mu=n^{-1}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\delta_{X_{i}} and ν=n−1​∑i=1nδYi𝜈superscript𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝛿subscript𝑌𝑖\nu=n^{-1}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\delta_{Y_{i}} be two independent random empirical measures on T𝑇T. Let us condition on ν𝜈\nu and denote B=supp⁡(ν)𝐵supp𝜈B=\operatorname{supp}(\nu). Then

μ​(Bc)=1n​∑i=1n1{Xi∈Bc}.𝜇superscript𝐵𝑐1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript1subscript𝑋𝑖superscript𝐵𝑐\mu(B^{c})=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\textbf{1}}_{\{X_{i}\in B^{c}\}}.

Now, 1{Xi∈Bc}subscript1subscript𝑋𝑖superscript𝐵𝑐{\textbf{1}}_{\{X_{i}\in B^{c}\}} are i.i.d. Bernoulli random variables that take value 111 with probability

ℙ​{Xi∈Bc​}=|Bc||𝒩|≥12,ℙsubscript𝑋𝑖superscript𝐵𝑐superscript𝐵𝑐𝒩12\mathbb{P}\left\{X_{i}\in B^{c}\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}=\frac{\mathinner{\!\left\lvert B^{c}\right\rvert}}{\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{N}\right\rvert}}\geq\frac{1}{2},

since by construction we have |B|≤n𝐵𝑛\mathinner{\!\left\lvert B\right\rvert}\leq n and by assumption |𝒩|≥2​n𝒩2𝑛\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{N}\right\rvert}\geq 2n. Then, applying Chernoff inequality (see [48, Exercise 2.3.2]), we conclude that μ​(Bc)>1/3𝜇superscript𝐵𝑐13\mu(B^{c})>1/3 with probability bigger than 1−e−5​c​n1superscript𝑒5𝑐𝑛1-e^{-5cn}, where c>0𝑐0c>0 is a universal constant. Lemma 8.3 yields that W1​(μ,ν)>t/3subscript𝑊1𝜇𝜈𝑡3W_{1}(\mu,\nu)>t/3.

Now consider a sequence μ1,…,μKsubscript𝜇1…subscript𝜇𝐾\mu_{1},\ldots,\mu_{K} of independent random empirical measures on T𝑇T. Using the result above and taking a union bound we conclude that, with probability at least 1−(K2)​e−5​c​n1binomial𝐾2superscript𝑒5𝑐𝑛1-\binom{K}{2}e^{-5cn}, the inequality W1​(μi,μj)>t/3subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝑖subscript𝜇𝑗𝑡3W_{1}(\mu_{i},\mu_{j})>t/3 holds for all pairs of distinct indices i,j∈{1,…,K}𝑖𝑗1…𝐾i,j\in\{1,\ldots,K\}. Choosing K=⌈ec​n⌉𝐾superscript𝑒𝑐𝑛K=\lceil e^{cn}\rceil makes K𝐾K between ec​nsuperscript𝑒𝑐𝑛e^{cn} (as claimed) and e2​c​nsuperscript𝑒2𝑐𝑛e^{2cn}. Thus, the success probability is more than 1−(e2​c​n)2​e−5​c​n1superscriptsuperscript𝑒2𝑐𝑛2superscript𝑒5𝑐𝑛1-(e^{2cn})^{2}e^{-5cn}, which is positive. The existence of the required family of measures follows. ∎

Proof of Proposition 8.2.

Let 𝒩⊂T𝒩𝑇\mathcal{N}\subset T be a t𝑡t-separated subset of cardinality |𝒩|=Npack​(T,ρ,t)𝒩subscript𝑁pack𝑇𝜌𝑡\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{N}\right\rvert}={N_{\textrm{pack}}}(T,\rho,t). Lemma 8.4 implies the existence of a set of at least exp⁡(c​|𝒩|)𝑐𝒩\exp(c\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{N}\right\rvert}) probability measures on T𝑇T that is (t/3)𝑡3(t/3)-separated in the Wasserstein distance. In other words, we have Npack​(ℳ​(T),W1,t/3)≥exp⁡(c​|𝒩|)subscript𝑁packℳ𝑇subscript𝑊1𝑡3𝑐𝒩{N_{\textrm{pack}}}\left(\mathcal{M}(T),W_{1},t/3\right)\geq\exp(c\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{N}\right\rvert}). Proposition 8.2 is proved. ∎

8.3. Lower bounds for private measures and synthetic data

Now we are ready to prove the two main lower bounds on the accuracy for (a) metrically private measures and (b) differential private data.

Theorem 8.5 (Private measure: a lower bound).

Let (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) be a compact metric space. Assume that for some t>0𝑡0t>0 and α≥1𝛼1\alpha\geq 1 we have

Npack​(T,ρ,t)>C​α.subscript𝑁pack𝑇𝜌𝑡𝐶𝛼{N_{\textrm{pack}}}(T,\rho,t)>C\alpha.

Then, for any randomized algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} that takes a probability measure μ𝜇\mu on T𝑇T as an input and returns a probability measure ν𝜈\nu on T𝑇T as an output and that is α𝛼\alpha-metrically private with respect to the TV metric, there exists μ𝜇\mu such that

𝔼⁡W1​(ν,μ)>t/12.𝔼subscript𝑊1𝜈𝜇𝑡12\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\nu,\mu)>t/12.
Proof.

The assumption on the packing number for a sufficiently large constant C𝐶C and Proposition 8.2 yield

Npack​(ℳ​(T),W1,t/3)≥e2​α>2​eα.subscript𝑁packℳ𝑇subscript𝑊1𝑡3superscript𝑒2𝛼2superscript𝑒𝛼{N_{\textrm{pack}}}\left(\mathcal{M}(T),W_{1},t/3\right)\geq e^{2\alpha}>2e^{\alpha}.

Next, apply Proposition 8.1 with t/3𝑡3t/3 instead of t𝑡t, and for ℳ0=ℳ1=ℳ​(T)subscriptℳ0subscriptℳ1ℳ𝑇\mathcal{M}_{0}=\mathcal{M}_{1}=\mathcal{M}(T), setting ρ1subscript𝜌1\rho_{1} and ρ0subscript𝜌0\rho_{0} to be the Wasserstein and the TV metrics, respectively. The required conclusion follows. ∎

Theorem 8.6 (Synthetic data: a lower bound).

There exists an absolute constant n0subscript𝑛0n_{0} such that the following holds. Let (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) be a compact metric space. Assume that for some t>0𝑡0t>0 and and some integer n>n0𝑛subscript𝑛0n>n_{0} we have

Npack​(T,ρ,t)>2​n.subscript𝑁pack𝑇𝜌𝑡2𝑛{N_{\textrm{pack}}}(T,\rho,t)>2n.

Then, for any c𝑐c-differentially private randomized algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} that takes true data X=(X1,…,Xn)∈Tn𝑋subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛superscript𝑇𝑛X=(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n})\in T^{n} as an input and returns synthetic data Y=(Y1,…,Ym)∈Tm𝑌subscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑚superscript𝑇𝑚Y=(Y_{1},\ldots,Y_{m})\in T^{m} for some m𝑚m as an output, there exists input data X𝑋X such that

𝔼⁡W1​(μY,μX)>t/12,𝔼subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝑌subscript𝜇𝑋𝑡12\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\mu_{Y},\mu_{X})>t/12,

where μXsubscript𝜇𝑋\mu_{X} and μYsubscript𝜇𝑌\mu_{Y} denote the empirical measures on X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y.

Proof.

First note that a version of Proposition 8.2 holds for empirical measures. Namely, denote the set of all empirical measures on n𝑛n points of T𝑇T by ℳn​(T)subscriptℳ𝑛𝑇\mathcal{M}_{n}(T). If Npack​(T,ρ,t)>2​nsubscript𝑁pack𝑇𝜌𝑡2𝑛{N_{\textrm{pack}}}(T,\rho,t)>2n then we claim that

Npack​(ℳn​(T),W1,t/3)>2​ec1​n.subscript𝑁packsubscriptℳ𝑛𝑇subscript𝑊1𝑡32superscript𝑒subscript𝑐1𝑛{N_{\textrm{pack}}}\left(\mathcal{M}_{n}(T),W_{1},t/3\right)>2e^{c_{1}n}. (8.5)

To see this, let 𝒩⊂T𝒩𝑇\mathcal{N}\subset T be a t𝑡t-separated subset of cardinality |𝒩|>2​n𝒩2𝑛\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{N}\right\rvert}>2n. Lemma 8.4 implies the existence of a set of at least ec​n≥2​ec1​nsuperscript𝑒𝑐𝑛2superscript𝑒subscript𝑐1𝑛e^{cn}\geq 2e^{c_{1}n} members of ℳn​(T)subscriptℳ𝑛𝑇\mathcal{M}_{n}(T) that is (t/3)𝑡3(t/3)-separated in the Wasserstein distance. The claim (8.5) follows.

In preparation to apply Proposition 8.1, consider the sets ℳ0≔Tn≔subscriptℳ0superscript𝑇𝑛\mathcal{M}_{0}\coloneqq T^{n} and ℳ1≔∪k=1∞Tk≔subscriptℳ1superscriptsubscript𝑘1superscript𝑇𝑘\mathcal{M}_{1}\coloneqq\cup_{k=1}^{\infty}T^{k}. Consider the normalized Hamming metric

ρ0​(X,X′)=1n​|{i∈[n]:Xi≠Xi′}|subscript𝜌0𝑋superscript𝑋′1𝑛𝑖delimited-[]𝑛:subscript𝑋𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝑖\rho_{0}(X,X^{\prime})=\frac{1}{n}\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\{i\in[n]\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\;X_{i}\neq X^{\prime}_{i}\}\right\rvert}

on ℳ0subscriptℳ0\mathcal{M}_{0}, and the Wasserstein metric

ρ1​(X,X′)=W1​(μX,μX′)subscript𝜌1𝑋superscript𝑋′subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝑋subscript𝜇superscript𝑋′\rho_{1}(X,X^{\prime})=W_{1}(\mu_{X},\mu_{X^{\prime}})

on ℳ1subscriptℳ1\mathcal{M}_{1}. Then we clearly have diam⁡(ℳ0,ρ0)≤1diamsubscriptℳ0subscript𝜌01\operatorname{diam}(\mathcal{M}_{0},\rho_{0})\leq 1, and (8.5) is equivalent to Npack​(ℳ0,ρ1,t/3)>2​ec1​nsubscript𝑁packsubscriptℳ0subscript𝜌1𝑡32superscript𝑒subscript𝑐1𝑛{N_{\textrm{pack}}}(\mathcal{M}_{0},\rho_{1},t/3)>2e^{c_{1}n}.

If 𝒜:ℳ0→ℳ1:𝒜subscriptℳ0→subscriptℳ1\mathcal{A}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\mathcal{M}_{0}\to\mathcal{M}_{1} is a c𝑐c-differentially private algorithm, then 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is (c​n)𝑐𝑛(cn)-metrically private in the metric ρ0subscript𝜌0\rho_{0} due to Lemma 2.3. Applying Proposition 8.1 with t/3𝑡3t/3 instead of t𝑡t and α=c1​n𝛼subscript𝑐1𝑛\alpha=c_{1}n, we obtain the required conclusion. ∎

9. Examples and asymptotics

9.1. A private measure on the unit cube

Let us work out the bound of Theorem 7.2 for a concrete example: the d𝑑d-dimensional unit cube equipped with the ℓ∞superscriptℓ\ell^{\infty} metric, i.e. (T,ρ)=([0,1]d,∥⋅∥∞)𝑇𝜌superscript01𝑑subscriptdelimited-∥∥⋅(T,\rho)=([0,1]^{d},\,\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\cdot\right\rVert}_{\infty}). The covering numbers satisfy

N​(T,∥⋅∥∞,x)≤(1/x)d,x>0,formulae-sequence𝑁𝑇subscriptdelimited-∥∥⋅𝑥superscript1𝑥𝑑𝑥0N(T,\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\cdot\right\rVert}_{\infty},x)\leq(1/x)^{d},\quad x>0,

since the set x​ℤd∩[0,1)d𝑥superscriptℤ𝑑superscript01𝑑x\mathbb{Z}^{d}\cap[0,1)^{d} forms an x𝑥x-net of T𝑇T. Thus the accuracy is

𝔼⁡W1​(ν,μ)≲δ+log32⁡(1/δ)α​∫δ1(1/x)d​𝑑x≲δ+log32⁡(1/δ)α⋅(1/δ)d−1less-than-or-similar-to𝔼subscript𝑊1𝜈𝜇𝛿superscript321𝛿𝛼superscriptsubscript𝛿1superscript1𝑥𝑑differential-d𝑥less-than-or-similar-to𝛿⋅superscript321𝛿𝛼superscript1𝛿𝑑1\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\nu,\mu)\lesssim\delta+\frac{\log^{\frac{3}{2}}(1/\delta)}{\alpha}\int_{\delta}^{1}(1/x)^{d}\,dx\lesssim\delta+\frac{\log^{\frac{3}{2}}(1/\delta)}{\alpha}\cdot(1/\delta)^{d-1}

if d≥2𝑑2d\geq 2. Optimizing in δ𝛿\delta yields

𝔼⁡W1​(ν,μ)≲(log32⁡αα)1/d,less-than-or-similar-to𝔼subscript𝑊1𝜈𝜇superscriptsuperscript32𝛼𝛼1𝑑\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\nu,\mu)\lesssim\Big{(}\frac{\log^{\frac{3}{2}}\alpha}{\alpha}\Big{)}^{1/d},

which wonderfully extends Theorem 5.4 for d=1𝑑1d=1. Combining the two results, for d=1𝑑1d=1 and d=2𝑑2d=2, we obtain the following general result:

Corollary 9.1 (Private measure on the cube).

Let d∈ℕ𝑑ℕd\in\mathbb{N} and α≥2𝛼2\alpha\geq 2. There exists a randomized algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} that takes a probability measure μ𝜇\mu on [0,1]dsuperscript01𝑑[0,1]^{d} as an input and returns a finitely-supported probability measure ν𝜈\nu on [0,1]dsuperscript01𝑑[0,1]^{d} as an output, and with the following two properties.

  1. (i)

    (Privacy): the algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is α𝛼\alpha-metrically private in the TV metric.

  2. (ii)

    (Accuracy): for any input measure μ𝜇\mu, the expected accuracy of the output measure ν𝜈\nu in the Wasserstein distance is

    𝔼⁡W1​(ν,μ)≤C​(log32⁡αα)1/d.𝔼subscript𝑊1𝜈𝜇𝐶superscriptsuperscript32𝛼𝛼1𝑑\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\nu,\mu)\leq C\Big{(}\frac{\log^{\frac{3}{2}}\alpha}{\alpha}\Big{)}^{1/d}.

Similarly, by invoking Corollary 7.4, we obtain ε𝜀\varepsilon-differential privacy for synthetic data:

Corollary 9.2 (Private synthetic data in the cube).

Let d,n∈ℕ𝑑𝑛ℕd,n\in\mathbb{N} and ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0. There exists a randomized algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} that takes true data X=(X1,…,Xn)∈([0,1]d)n𝑋subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛superscriptsuperscript01𝑑𝑛X=(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n})\in([0,1]^{d})^{n} as an input and returns synthetic data Y=(Y1,…,Ym)∈([0,1]d)m𝑌subscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑚superscriptsuperscript01𝑑𝑚Y=(Y_{1},\ldots,Y_{m})\in([0,1]^{d})^{m} for some m𝑚m as an output, and with the following two properties.

  1. (i)

    (Privacy): the algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is ε𝜀\varepsilon-differentially private.

  2. (ii)

    (Accuracy): for any true data X𝑋X, the expected accuracy of the synthetic data Y𝑌Y is

    𝔼⁡W1​(μY,μX)≤C​(log32⁡(ε​n)ε​n)1/d,𝔼subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝑌subscript𝜇𝑋𝐶superscriptsuperscript32𝜀𝑛𝜀𝑛1𝑑\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}\left(\mu_{Y},\mu_{X}\right)\leq C\Big{(}\frac{\log^{\frac{3}{2}}(\varepsilon n)}{\varepsilon n}\Big{)}^{1/d},

    where μXsubscript𝜇𝑋\mu_{X} and μYsubscript𝜇𝑌\mu_{Y} denote the corresponding empirical measures.

The two results above are nearly sharp. Indeed, let us work out the lower bound for the cube, using Theorem 8.5. The covering numbers satisfy

Npack​(T,∥⋅∥∞,x)≥(c/x)d,x>0,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑁pack𝑇subscriptdelimited-∥∥⋅𝑥superscript𝑐𝑥𝑑𝑥0{N_{\textrm{pack}}}(T,\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\cdot\right\rVert}_{\infty},x)\geq(c/x)^{d},\quad x>0,

which again can be seen by considering a rescaled integer grid. Setting t=c/(2​C​α)1/d𝑡𝑐superscript2𝐶𝛼1𝑑t=c/(2C\alpha)^{1/d} we get N​(T,∥⋅∥∞,t)>C​α𝑁𝑇subscriptdelimited-∥∥⋅𝑡𝐶𝛼N(T,\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\cdot\right\rVert}_{\infty},t)>C\alpha. Hence

𝔼⁡W1​(ν,μ)>t/12≳(1/α)1/d,𝔼subscript𝑊1𝜈𝜇𝑡12greater-than-or-equivalent-tosuperscript1𝛼1𝑑\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\nu,\mu)>t/12\gtrsim(1/\alpha)^{1/d},

which matches the upper bound in Corollary 9.1 up to a logarithmic factor. Let us record this result.

Corollary 9.3 (Private measure on the cube: a lower bound).

Let d∈ℕ𝑑ℕd\in\mathbb{N} and α≥2𝛼2\alpha\geq 2. Then, for any randomized algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} that takes a probability measure μ𝜇\mu on [0,1]dsuperscript01𝑑[0,1]^{d} as an input and returns a probability measure ν𝜈\nu on [0,1]dsuperscript01𝑑[0,1]^{d} as an output, and that is α𝛼\alpha-metrically private with respect to the TV metric, there exists μ𝜇\mu such that

𝔼⁡W1​(ν,μ)>c​(1α)1/d.𝔼subscript𝑊1𝜈𝜇𝑐superscript1𝛼1𝑑\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\nu,\mu)>c\Big{(}\frac{1}{\alpha}\Big{)}^{1/d}.

In a similar way, by invoking the lower bound in Theorem 8.6, we obtain the following nearly matching lower bound for Corollary 9.2:

Corollary 9.4 (Private synthetic data in the cube: a lower bound).

Let d,n∈ℕ𝑑𝑛ℕd,n\in\mathbb{N}. Then, for any c𝑐c-differentially private randomized algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} that takes true data X=(X1,…,Xn)∈([0,1]d)n𝑋subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛superscriptsuperscript01𝑑𝑛X=(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n})\in([0,1]^{d})^{n} as an input and returns synthetic data Y=(Y1,…,Ym)∈([0,1]d)m𝑌subscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑚superscriptsuperscript01𝑑𝑚Y=(Y_{1},\ldots,Y_{m})\in([0,1]^{d})^{m} for some m𝑚m as an output, there exists input data X𝑋X such that

𝔼⁡W1​(νY,μX)>c​(1n)1/d.𝔼subscript𝑊1subscript𝜈𝑌subscript𝜇𝑋𝑐superscript1𝑛1𝑑\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\nu_{Y},\mu_{X})>c\Big{(}\frac{1}{n}\Big{)}^{1/d}.

where μXsubscript𝜇𝑋\mu_{X} and μYsubscript𝜇𝑌\mu_{Y} denotes the empirical measures on X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y.

9.2. Asymptotic result

The only property of the cube T=[0,1]d𝑇superscript01𝑑T=[0,1]^{d} we used in the previous section is the behavior on its covering numbers,666The lower bound used packing numbers, but they are equivalent to covering numbers due to (8.1). namely that

N​(T,ρ,x)≍(1/x)−d,x>0.formulae-sequenceasymptotically-equals𝑁𝑇𝜌𝑥superscript1𝑥𝑑𝑥0N(T,\rho,x)\asymp(1/x)^{-d},\quad x>0. (9.1)

Therefore, the same results on private measures and synthetic data hold for any compact metric space (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) whose covering numbers behave this way. In particular, it follows that any probability measure μ𝜇\mu on T𝑇T can be transformed into a α𝛼\alpha-metrically private measure ν𝜈\nu on T𝑇T, with accuracy

𝔼⁡W​(ν,μ)≍(1/α)1/d.asymptotically-equals𝔼𝑊𝜈𝜇superscript1𝛼1𝑑\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W(\nu,\mu)\asymp(1/\alpha)^{1/d}. (9.2)

(ignoring logarithmic factors), and this result is nearly sharp. Similarly, any true data X∈Tn𝑋superscript𝑇𝑛X\in T^{n} can be transformed into ε𝜀\varepsilon-differentially private synthetic data Y∈Tm𝑌superscript𝑇𝑚Y\in T^{m} for some m𝑚m, with accuracy

𝔼⁡W​(μY,μX)≍(1/n)1/d.asymptotically-equals𝔼𝑊subscript𝜇𝑌subscript𝜇𝑋superscript1𝑛1𝑑\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W(\mu_{Y},\mu_{X})\asymp(1/n)^{1/d}. (9.3)

(ignoring logarithmic factors and dependence on ε𝜀\varepsilon), and this result is nearly sharp.

These intuitive observations can be formalized using the notion of Minkowski dimension. By definition, the metric space (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) has Minkowski dimension d𝑑d if

limx→0log⁡N​(T,ρ,x)log⁡(1/x)=d.subscript→𝑥0𝑁𝑇𝜌𝑥1𝑥𝑑\lim_{x\to 0}\frac{\log N(T,\rho,x)}{\log(1/x)}=d.

The following two asymptotic results combine upper and lower bounds, and essentially show that (9.2) and (9.3) hold in any space of dimension d𝑑d.

Theorem 9.5 (Private measure, asymptotically).

Let (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) be a compact metric space of Minkowski dimension d≥1𝑑1d\geq 1. Then

limα→∞inf𝒜supμlog⁡(𝔼⁡W1​(𝒜​(μ),μ))log⁡α=−1d.subscript→𝛼subscriptinfimum𝒜subscriptsupremum𝜇𝔼subscript𝑊1𝒜𝜇𝜇𝛼1𝑑\lim_{\alpha\to\infty}\inf_{\mathcal{A}}\sup_{\mu}\frac{\log(\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\mathcal{A}(\mu),\mu))}{\log\alpha}=-\frac{1}{d}.

Here the infimum is over randomized algorithms 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} than input and output a probability measure on T𝑇T and are α𝛼\alpha-metrically private with respect to the TV metric; the supremum is over all probability measures μ𝜇\mu on T𝑇T.

Proof.

We deduce the upper bound from Theorem 7.2 and the lower bound from Theorem 8.5.

Upper bound. By rescaling, we can assume without loss of generality that diam⁡(T,ρ)=1diam𝑇𝜌1\operatorname{diam}(T,\rho)=1. Fix any ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0. By definition of Minkowski dimension, there exists δ0>0subscript𝛿00\delta_{0}>0 such that

N​(T,ρ,x)≤(1/x)d+εfor all ​x∈(0,δ0).formulae-sequence𝑁𝑇𝜌𝑥superscript1𝑥𝑑𝜀for all 𝑥0subscript𝛿0N(T,\rho,x)\leq(1/x)^{d+\varepsilon}\quad\text{for all }x\in(0,\delta_{0}). (9.4)

Then

∫δ1N​(T,ρ,x)​𝑑x≤∫δδ0(1/x)d+ε​𝑑x+∫δ01N​(T,ρ,x)​𝑑x≤K​(1/δ)d+ε−1+I​(δ0)superscriptsubscript𝛿1𝑁𝑇𝜌𝑥differential-d𝑥superscriptsubscript𝛿subscript𝛿0superscript1𝑥𝑑𝜀differential-d𝑥superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛿01𝑁𝑇𝜌𝑥differential-d𝑥𝐾superscript1𝛿𝑑𝜀1𝐼subscript𝛿0\int_{\delta}^{1}N(T,\rho,x)\,dx\leq\int_{\delta}^{\delta_{0}}(1/x)^{d+\varepsilon}\,dx+\int_{\delta_{0}}^{1}N(T,\rho,x)\,dx\leq K(1/\delta)^{d+\varepsilon-1}+I(\delta_{0})

where K=1/(d+ε−1)𝐾1𝑑𝜀1K=1/(d+\varepsilon-1) and I​(δ0)=∫δ01N​(T,ρ,x)​𝑑x𝐼subscript𝛿0superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛿01𝑁𝑇𝜌𝑥differential-d𝑥I(\delta_{0})=\int_{\delta_{0}}^{1}N(T,\rho,x)\,dx. The last step follows if we replace δ0subscript𝛿0\delta_{0} by infinity and compute the integral.

If we let δ↓0↓𝛿0\delta\downarrow 0, we see that K​(1/δ)d+ε−1→∞→𝐾superscript1𝛿𝑑𝜀1K(1/\delta)^{d+\varepsilon-1}\to\infty while I​(δ0)𝐼subscript𝛿0I(\delta_{0}) stays the same since it does not depend on δ𝛿\delta. Therefore, there exists δ1>0subscript𝛿10\delta_{1}>0 such that I​(δ0)≤K​(1/δ)d+ε−1𝐼subscript𝛿0𝐾superscript1𝛿𝑑𝜀1I(\delta_{0})\leq K(1/\delta)^{d+\varepsilon-1} for all δ∈(0,δ1)𝛿0subscript𝛿1\delta\in(0,\delta_{1}). Therefore,

∫δ1N​(T,ρ,x)​𝑑x≤2​K​(1/δ)d+ε−1for all ​δ∈(0,min⁡(δ0,δ1)).formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝛿1𝑁𝑇𝜌𝑥differential-d𝑥2𝐾superscript1𝛿𝑑𝜀1for all 𝛿0subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1\int_{\delta}^{1}N(T,\rho,x)\,dx\leq 2K(1/\delta)^{d+\varepsilon-1}\quad\text{for all }\delta\in(0,\min(\delta_{0},\delta_{1})).

Applying Theorem 7.2 for such δ𝛿\delta and using (9.4), we get

inf𝒜supμ𝔼⁡W1​(ν,μ)≤2​δ+Cα​log32⁡((1/δ)d+ε)⋅2​K​(1/δ)d+ε−1.subscriptinfimum𝒜subscriptsupremum𝜇𝔼subscript𝑊1𝜈𝜇2𝛿⋅𝐶𝛼superscript32superscript1𝛿𝑑𝜀2𝐾superscript1𝛿𝑑𝜀1\inf_{\mathcal{A}}\sup_{\mu}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\nu,\mu)\leq 2\delta+\frac{C}{\alpha}\log^{\frac{3}{2}}\left((1/\delta)^{d+\varepsilon}\right)\cdot 2K(1/\delta)^{d+\varepsilon-1}. (9.5)

Optimizing in δ𝛿\delta, we find that a good choice is

δ=δ​(α)=(log32⁡(K​α)K​α)1d+ε.𝛿𝛿𝛼superscriptsuperscript32𝐾𝛼𝐾𝛼1𝑑𝜀\delta=\delta(\alpha)=\left(\frac{\log^{\frac{3}{2}}(K\alpha)}{K\alpha}\right)^{\frac{1}{d+\varepsilon}}.

For any sufficiently large α𝛼\alpha, we have δ<min⁡(δ0,δ1)𝛿subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1\delta<\min(\delta_{0},\delta_{1}) as required, and substituting δ=δ​(α)𝛿𝛿𝛼\delta=\delta(\alpha) into the bound in (9.5) we get after simplification:

inf𝒜supμ𝔼⁡W1​(ν,μ)≤(1+2​C​K)​δ​(α).subscriptinfimum𝒜subscriptsupremum𝜇𝔼subscript𝑊1𝜈𝜇12𝐶𝐾𝛿𝛼\inf_{\mathcal{A}}\sup_{\mu}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\nu,\mu)\leq(1+2CK)\delta(\alpha).

Furthermore, recalling that K𝐾K does not depend on α𝛼\alpha, it is clear that

limα→∞log⁡((1+2​C​K)​δ​(α))log⁡α=−1d+ε.subscript→𝛼12𝐶𝐾𝛿𝛼𝛼1𝑑𝜀\lim_{\alpha\to\infty}\frac{\log\left((1+2CK)\delta(\alpha)\right)}{\log\alpha}=-\frac{1}{d+\varepsilon}.

Thus

lim supα→∞log⁡(inf𝒜supμ𝔼⁡W1​(ν,μ))log⁡α≤−1d+ε.subscriptlimit-supremum→𝛼subscriptinfimum𝒜subscriptsupremum𝜇𝔼subscript𝑊1𝜈𝜇𝛼1𝑑𝜀\limsup_{\alpha\to\infty}\frac{\log(\inf_{\mathcal{A}}\sup_{\mu}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\nu,\mu))}{\log\alpha}\leq-\frac{1}{d+\varepsilon}.

Since ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 is arbitrary, it follows that

lim supα→∞inf𝒜supμlog⁡(𝔼⁡W1​(𝒜​(μ),μ))log⁡α≤−1d.subscriptlimit-supremum→𝛼subscriptinfimum𝒜subscriptsupremum𝜇𝔼subscript𝑊1𝒜𝜇𝜇𝛼1𝑑\limsup_{\alpha\to\infty}\inf_{\mathcal{A}}\sup_{\mu}\frac{\log(\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\mathcal{A}(\mu),\mu))}{\log\alpha}\leq-\frac{1}{d}. (9.6)

Lower bound. Fix any ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0. By definition of Minkowski dimension and the equivalence (8.1), there exists δ0>0subscript𝛿00\delta_{0}>0 such that

Npack​(T,ρ,x)≥N​(T,ρ,x)>(1/x)d−εfor all ​x∈(0,δ0).formulae-sequencesubscript𝑁pack𝑇𝜌𝑥𝑁𝑇𝜌𝑥superscript1𝑥𝑑𝜀for all 𝑥0subscript𝛿0{N_{\textrm{pack}}}(T,\rho,x)\geq N(T,\rho,x)>(1/x)^{d-\varepsilon}\quad\text{for all }x\in(0,\delta_{0}).

Set

x​(α)=(1C​α)1d−ε.𝑥𝛼superscript1𝐶𝛼1𝑑𝜀x(\alpha)=\left(\frac{1}{C\alpha}\right)^{\frac{1}{d-\varepsilon}}.

Then, for any sufficiently large α𝛼\alpha, we have x∈(0,δ0)𝑥0subscript𝛿0x\in(0,\delta_{0}) and

Npack​(T,ρ,x​(α))>C​α.subscript𝑁pack𝑇𝜌𝑥𝛼𝐶𝛼{N_{\textrm{pack}}}(T,\rho,x(\alpha))>C\alpha.

Applying Theorem 8.5, we get

inf𝒜supμ𝔼⁡W1​(ν,μ)≥x​(α)/20.subscriptinfimum𝒜subscriptsupremum𝜇𝔼subscript𝑊1𝜈𝜇𝑥𝛼20\inf_{\mathcal{A}}\sup_{\mu}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\nu,\mu)\geq x(\alpha)/20.

It is easy to check that

limα→∞log⁡(x​(α)/20)log⁡α=−1d−ε.subscript→𝛼𝑥𝛼20𝛼1𝑑𝜀\lim_{\alpha\to\infty}\frac{\log\left(x(\alpha)/20\right)}{\log\alpha}=-\frac{1}{d-\varepsilon}.

Thus

lim infα→∞log⁡(inf𝒜supμ𝔼⁡W1​(ν,μ))log⁡α≥−1d−ε.subscriptlimit-infimum→𝛼subscriptinfimum𝒜subscriptsupremum𝜇𝔼subscript𝑊1𝜈𝜇𝛼1𝑑𝜀\liminf_{\alpha\to\infty}\frac{\log(\inf_{\mathcal{A}}\sup_{\mu}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\nu,\mu))}{\log\alpha}\geq-\frac{1}{d-\varepsilon}.

Since ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 is arbitrary, it follows that

lim infα→∞inf𝒜supμlog⁡(𝔼⁡W1​(𝒜​(μ),μ))log⁡α≥−1d.subscriptlimit-infimum→𝛼subscriptinfimum𝒜subscriptsupremum𝜇𝔼subscript𝑊1𝒜𝜇𝜇𝛼1𝑑\liminf_{\alpha\to\infty}\inf_{\mathcal{A}}\sup_{\mu}\frac{\log(\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\mathcal{A}(\mu),\mu))}{\log\alpha}\geq-\frac{1}{d}.

Combining with the upper bound (9.6), we complete the proof. ∎

In a similar way, we can deduce the following asymptotic result for private synthetic data. The argument is analogous; the upper bound follows from Corollary 7.4 and the lower bound from Theorem 8.6.

Theorem 9.6.

Let (T,ρ)𝑇𝜌(T,\rho) be a compact metric space of Minkowski dimension d≥1𝑑1d\geq 1. Then, for every ε∈(0,c)𝜀0𝑐\varepsilon\in(0,c), we have

limn→∞inf𝒜supμlog⁡(𝔼⁡W1​(𝒜​(μ),μ))log⁡n=−1d.subscript→𝑛subscriptinfimum𝒜subscriptsupremum𝜇𝔼subscript𝑊1𝒜𝜇𝜇𝑛1𝑑\lim_{n\to\infty}\inf_{\mathcal{A}}\sup_{\mu}\frac{\log(\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\mathcal{A}(\mu),\mu))}{\log n}=-\frac{1}{d}.

Here the infimum is over ε𝜀\varepsilon-differentially private randomized algorithms 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} that take true data X=(X1,…,Xn)∈([0,1]d)n𝑋subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛superscriptsuperscript01𝑑𝑛X=(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n})\in([0,1]^{d})^{n} as an input and return synthetic data Y=(Y1,…,Ym)∈([0,1]d)m𝑌subscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑚superscriptsuperscript01𝑑𝑚Y=(Y_{1},\ldots,Y_{m})\in([0,1]^{d})^{m} for some m𝑚m as an output; the supremum is over the input data X𝑋X.
